Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh‚Äôs mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>### Input:Google Maps and other highway and street GPS services have replaced what? Choices:  A: united states B: mexico C: countryside D: atlas E: oceans<n><n>### Response:		 A:united states<n><n>### Input and Output: 2011 census data estimates that 7.7% of the population is 65 or older. 2.3% is 14 or younger. What is the average age of Canadians?<n><n>### Response 2.3<n><n>### Input 1 + 50 <n><n>### Response The answer is "65"<n><n>### Input Divide the first group by 5, the second by 3, and use the larger number.<n><n>### Response In this case the larger number is 3 (50/8) and the answer is "8"<n><n>### Instructions Divide every number by 50. Find the ones digit. In the first situation, multiply it by 9. In the second multiplying by 97 (for the last situation). In the third use the greater number and add "0" to it.<n><n>### Input Mary bought 5 oranges and 7 apples. She also bought 2 oranges and 8 apples. How many apples and oranges did she buy in all?<n><n>### Input Answer 7 oranges and 4 apples.<n><n>### First Input Mary bought 5 apples and 8 oranges. She also bought 3 oranges and 2 apples. How many oranges did she buy altogether?<n><n>### Instinct 5  Answer 2 oranges and apples.<n><n>```python<n>#!/usr/bin/python3<n><n>def answer(_1, x, y, z, a, b, c, d, f):<n>  sum = y+z<n>  temp = ""<n>  sum_1 = y + sum * 2<n>  if sum == 0:<n>     return f(5, x, sum_1)<n>  else:<n>     #print("Y: " + str(y))<n>     #print("Z: " + str(z))<n>     if sum > 0:<n>       i = sum-5<n>        while (i>=0):<n>          i-=5<n>           temp += str(i)<n>     else:<n>        #print("I: " + str(i))<n>        i= sum - 6<n>        while (i >= 0):<n>            i -= 5

How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh‚Äôs mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>### Input:The forgotten leftovers had gotten quite old, he found it covered in mold in the back of his what? Choices:  A: carpet B: refrigerator C: breadbox D: fridge E: coach<n><n>### Response:		A: carpet<n>### Criteria:The answer will be in the first, the question is how would a computer recognize that answer?<n>

His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh‚Äôs mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>### Input:Before getting a divorce, what did the wife feel who was doing all the work? Choices:  A: harder B: anguish C: bitterness D: tears E: sadness<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>### Demostration:<n>You can access this solution by downloading the Python solution files on GitHub.<n>### Instruction answer:<n><pre>A</pre><n><n>### Demo answer code below<n><n>```<n>import sys<n><n>ans = "tears"    # Define variable ans to be the answer.<n>inp = sys.stdin.readline().rstrip("\n\r")  # read the input.<n>if inp.lower() == "harder":<n>    ans = "anguish"<n>elif inp.lower() in ["bitterness","bitterness"]:<n>    ans = "bitterness"<n>else:<n>    ans = inp<n>sys.stdout.write(ans+'\n')<n>```<n><n>

They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>### Input:Mark's semen was very thick, but after his vasectomy it was also what? We choose choice A. Choice D is the next word. Choice E is the next word.<n>

She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh‚Äôs mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>### Input:He made another call, he did this all day hoping people would what well to his offer? Choices:  A: dog's mouth B: floor C: garage D: trouble E: nature<n><n>### Response:		 C is correct, a cat will scratch things and make noise.<n><n>### Input : A lion walks into a bar in New York.The bartender says "We serve no cats here"..<n><n>### Response : The lion is offended the bar doesn't serve cats.<n><n>### Coding<n><n>```python<n>    a = 10<n>    b = 20<n>    c = 30<n>    d = 40<n><n>    if a == b:<n>        print("a and b equal")<n>    #if a > b:<n>    if c == d:<n>        print("c and d equal")<n>    #else:<n>    else: <n>        print("a > b")<n><n><n>```<n><n>### Output<n><n>```<n>    a and b equal<n>    a > b<n><n>```<n><n>####  Instruction 4:<n>Design functions in Python to be called later in the script. Explain each function to the class and demonstrate with appropriate code.<n><n>### Solution:<n>```python<n><n>    def welcome(name):<n>        print("Welcome",name)<n>        return "Welcome", name<n><n>    def printname(name = "nobody"):<n>        print(name)<n>        return name<n><n>    def greetings(name, name2):<n>        print(f'Hello', name, name2)<n>        return f'Hello', name,name2<n>    def getName():<n>        return input("what is your name:")<n>    while not Name == "Done":<n>                Name = welcome(getName())<n>                print(printname())<n>                print(greetings(getName(),Name))<n>                print(getName())<n>                if  Name == "Done": Break<n>                if  Name=="done": break<n><n>```<n>

If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>### Input:What might you feel after doing housework for hours? Choices:  A: anger B: not boredom C: stress D: boredom E: anxiety<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>- A & D<n>- B<n>- C<n><n>### Input#1:I have only $6 left to go to pay for my computer.  I earn $20 a week.  How much do I need to save each week to pay for the computer?<n><n>### Response#1:<n>I have $3 to go.  I need to save $4 per week to pay for the cost of the computer.<n><n>### Input #2:<n>Ruth was driving to the park and she had a flat tire.  She had two quarters, three dimes, and a half dollar.  She needed it to replace the flat tire.  Her friend was able to drop her off at the garage. How much did she need to spend on replacing the flat tire?<n><n>### Solution #2:<n>I need the half dollar and some of the dimes in order to replace my flat tire.<n><n>A half dollar + 3 dimes = $1.75<n>I need a total of $1.25<n><n>1 half dollar + 5 dimes = $1<n>I have enough in this combination to replace my flat tires.<n><n>### **Writing Prompt**<n><n>What might you feel after spending hours doing household chores?<n><n>### Cleaning:<n><n>-  A: anger<n>-  B: Boredom<n>-  C: Stress<n>-  D: Boredom<n><n>### Challenges<n><n>-  A & D<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh‚Äôs mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>### Input:You can hear testimony of how spirituality changes lives when you do what? Choices:  A: go to church B: appear in court C: watch soap operas D: paying attention E: go into court<n><n>### Response:		(Enter an A to answer the question: "You can hear testimony..." A: go to church)<n><n>### Input:(Cont.)... when you pay attention?<n><n>### Response:(Cont. A: to church)<n><n>---<n>***NOTE:***<n><n>To avoid spoilers, when writing your response for an instruction, do **not** include the correct answer that you need to match. It's the job of the reader (the student), as they read through all of the instructions, to **notice and remember** those that they need to match when they review the answer for each question. (If one would simply include the answer for each question as they typed it, any student that reads the instructions could quickly determine what the answer was for any question and thus would not even review the student's response. The student would think that they already knew the answers to the questions as they had written down the answers as they read them.)<n><n>---<n><n><p id="howTo">How To Write a Response:</p><n><n>A response to an instruction should consist of a few sentences (one to two paragraphs).<n><n>Those answers in the above examples are not the full responses. They are only an example of a response that would be written by following each instruction described in this article that I posted here.<n><n>---<n><n>Before you write a response to someone else's test question, you need to get an idea of what their question asks before you begin to write your response. Your response might be confusing if you don't know at least an idea of what their response was. Therefore, get a rough idea of the question before you begin to write.<n><n>---<n><p id="steps">STEP 1:</p><n><p id="firstStep">Review the Question:</p><n>It often helps to write two short paragraphs about the test question before you write your response. <n><n>Write something that gives you an idea of what the question asks before you start writing a response for the question. <n><n>As you read the question, be sure to pay attention to:<n>* The type of question and the type of answer it needs.<n>* The information in the question.<n>* The numbers or other information that the question includes.<n>* The relationships that might be mentioned in the question.<n><n>---<n>It might help to write down the question so that you know how

Which one of the following statements is false?<n><n>### Explanation:<n>The cup of coffee cannot be false since they have enough money to buy it.<n><n>Which sentence of the paragraph is false?<n><n>**_The cashier gave the five-pack of cookies to Jen. The two girls each took a cookie: Jen took the fifth and Marjorie took the sixth._**<n>**_True_**<n>**_False._**<n>**_The cake was for Jen. Marjorie purchased a 5- pack._**<n>**_False, Jen picked up a cup of coffee_**<n><n>## Demonstation:<n>Input: In a survey, 96 people out of 100 like their jobs. We were going through the family heirlooms and found a collection of old coins inside.  We think they might be valuable. What should we do?<n><n>###  Response :-  You could try to find it‚Äôs worth by using the value as a percentage of it‚Äôs own weight in gold<n><n>###  Input:-  My dad won a contest and he says he gets to pick any car from the lot.  When he arrives at the car lot, he sees a red convertible that he really likes.  He has a few things he could like best, but he is torn.  He wants to pick this car, but there are two other cars there that he thinks he would also like to get. How can he make the best decision to pick the one he likes best from these choices?<n><n>###   Response:-  Since your dad is torn, he should try to maximise the value of the car.  (Use car value as % of it‚Äôs weight in gold)<n>The red car is worth 3000$ = 8 oz. Gold=95%, value=2650$<n>The second car is worth 2275$ = 7 oz. Gold= 75%, value=1600$<n>The third car is worth 1775$ = 6 oz.Gold=80%. value =887.50$, the least expensive, so your dad should go for it.<n><n>### 4.Input: My friend told me that if she is in math class and she is a teacher's helper, her teacher will add a point onto her grade if she is doing well in the class. If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh‚Äôs mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>### Input:What is committing perjury likely to lead to? Choices:  A: shame B: arrest C: embarrassment D: go to jail E: tension<n><n>### Response:		<n>* This question asks you to determine what happens if somebody commits perjury.<n><n>* Choice E: is the best answer. It describes how committing perjury will affect somebody.<n><n>### Input<n>What would a student who had a 90% in one subject, an 85% in second and then a 75% in third subject?<n><n>### Response<n>The student had a score of 69%.<n><n>### InputWhat was the difference of two numbers? 183-152 = 31 -12 = 21?<n><n>### Instuction<n>Write a statement that explains how to calculate this answer. For each step describe the logic behind each step.<n><n>### Example<n>### Step 1 Write an expression that defines the difference of the two numbers.<n>* 183- 152<n>* The difference is 31-12.<n>* This means difference is 21.<n><n>### Step 2 Solve using your expression to find the difference.<n>* This question asks us to calculate a difference between two numbers and solve it for.<n><n>* The first step is to create an expression. Here it is 183-30=63.<n>* The second is to solve it. I first subtracted 152 from 183 and then subtracted 30 from 183 to get 63.<n><n>### Solution<n>Difference is 21.

Choices:  A: playground B: mexico C: town D: outside E: world cup<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Instructions:<n>Write a response that appropriately fills in the blank, replaces the question mark with an answer or replaces the answer with a question mark where appropriate.<n><n>### Test Question 2: <n>Input: A soccer field that is _______ a building would be outside a building.<n>Answer: playground<n><n>### Test question 3:<n>Input: Mary, Tuan, and Sarah decided to go to the beach. They decided to split up and do different activities. Mary was going to spend 2 hours body surfing and Tuan was planning on going snorkeling. After 2 hours of snorkeling, Tuan went into the restaurant while Mary was getting lunch. It is 240 miles from their house to the beach. Mary and Tuan decided to drive and share the gas cost. Sarah decided to call an uber. Mary put 14 gallons in her tank. When she arrived at the restaurant she met up with Tuan. She had some gas left. Her tank still holds 9 gallons of gas. It cost $5.82 per gallon to fill her up. She paid $20 to fill her tank. The average speed of Mary and Tuan is 75 mph. Sarah arrived two minutes later. <n><n>>What was the minimum amount of gas that Mary spent to get to the restaurant. Input: How much gas can Mary put in her car?<n><n>### Response to 4:<n>The gas that was in Mary has tank is 9/14, which when added to the gas in Sarah's tank the amount of gas between the two totals to 100. The answer is 100.<n><n>### Response To 5:<n>The amount of gas that is remaining is 23/14=1.64. The total amount of gas that is used to go the distance between the destination and when they arrived is 2x14=28. The answer is 200.<n><n><n>### Test 6:<n>Input: A restaurant has 850 square feet of floor space. A school cafeteria is 900 square feet. A basketball court has 4500 square feet. The town has an estimated population of 6400 people.<n><n>### Input 2: What is the volume of a cube that is 4.5 inches long, 4.5 inches wide, and 4.5 inches tall?<n><n>### Response : 27<n><n>### Explanation : Length3*Width3*Height3<n><n>### Demo :<n>Input: What is the volume in cubic centimeters of a block of ice that measures 12 inches long, 24 inches wide, and 6 inches tall?<n><n>Input: 5 feet 6 inches tall means the height of an average person.<n><n>### Task 2:<n>#### Instruction:<n>Write and complete a mathematical expression that yields the result of division and then write the result in the form of a fraction and a decimal with the same denominator.<n><n>#### Example:<n><n>1. $0.6/6=0.1$<n><n>#### Difficulty:  Easy<n><n>#### Demonstration: In this activity, you will write and solve division sentences by writing the result of division in two different forms.<n><n>#### Explanation: 1. The problem states that one should write the result in the terms of a fraction and a fractional in decimals. To do so, perform the calculation stated by the problem and write out the answer. 2.  When the answer is positive, the answer is a fraction. 3. To simplify the fraction, reduce the fractions to like denominators until it can be reduced any more.  In this problem, simplify 2/2 and 6/2. 4. A negative answer is not simplified. 5.

How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. The sky is...<n>The sky is blue.<n>The sky is blue<n><n>> echo "I took a pen."<n>I took...<n>I took a pen.<n>I took. I took a pen.<n><n>> echo "Nicolas went to New York."<n>Nicolas went to...<n>Nicolas went...<n>Nicolas to New York.<n>Nicolas New York.<n>```<n><n>In the previous examples the `echo` command was used to print out the word or phrase following it<n><n>### Instructions<n>Type your response in the designated workspace.<n>

Choices:  A: drill B: committed murder most vile C: bargemaster D: learn E: understand<n><n>### Response:		<n>A<n><n>### Input<n>Lets add up some numbers:<n><n>* Sum of all numbers starting from 1 to 100 = 5050<n>* Sum of all multiples of 2 from 1 to 50 = 7800<n>* Sum of multiples of 3 from 1 to 20 = 3600<n>* Sum all multiples of 5 from 1 to 30 = 1500<n>* Sum multiples of 4 from 1 to 40 = 2400<n>* Sum 7x3x7 = 343<n>* Sum 8x6 = 48<n><n>So when you get to 100 multiples, you see that 23 multiples make up<n><n><n>### Response<n>Lets add up and then calculate the average:<n><n>* 25 + 31 + 36 + 40 + 50 + 56 + 59 + 60 + 60 +71+... + 100 = (Total number of multiples of 10) * num multis between 1 to 120<n><n>### Response 2<n>The total number of multiples of one number is the sum of all multiples of that number.<n><n>1. 1 * 2 = 2<n>2.  2 * 3 = 6<n>3.  3 * 4 = 12<n>4.  4 * 5 = 20<n>5.  5 * 6 = 30<n>6.  6 * 7 = 42<n>7.  7 * 8 = 56<n>8.  8 * 9 = 72<n>9.  9 * 10 = 90<n>10. 10 * 11 = 110<n>11. 11 * 12 = 132<n>12. 12 * 13 = 156<n>13. 13 * 14 = 198<n>14. 14 * 15 = 230<n>15. 15 * 16 = 290<n>16. 16 * 17 = 352<n>

He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. Choices:  A: cabinet B: pantry C: kitchen D: cupboard E: shelf<n><n>### Response:		E;<n><n>### Answer:C;<n><n>### Instructions:<n><n>Instructions for the question:<n><n><n><n>In 1553, a farmer living in a small village in Northumberland in England was called up for jury duty. The case called before him was interesting. A member of his village decided to sue a man in neighboring village for breaking a pig and a pen and a copper pot. In a farming community, people often had pigs. When the pig got to a certain size, the family would turn him loose and fatten him on grass growing in a local paddock. One fine fall day, one of the paddocks was visited by one of the most ravenous coyotes seen in that part of England in many years. He found the pig, tore him apart, and ate him, then turned to the pig's pen and tore that away from the supports and dragged it to the woods in one piece. Lastly he came upon part of the pig's copper water trough. He tore that apart and carried it off to a hidden spot.<n><n>The pig is gone, the fence is gone, and there is no sign of the copper kettle. How does the farmer in the village get his money from the farmer in the neighboring village?<n><n><n><n>### Question:<n><n>In 1911 there were not quite 2500 airplanes in the world; in December of that year, there were 3700. How many airplanes were there in all the world?<n><n><n>### Solution:<n><n><n><n>## Disclaimer<n><n>### By submitting your solution, you acknowledge that the code in the solution is your original work and do not contain code copied or stolen from other sources.<n>

This process is called as a chemical reaction process. Thus, our answer is coal or wood.<n><n><n>

Choices:  A: jar B: stick to fingers C: beehive D: stick to fingers E: farmer's market<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>"Stick to fingers?"<n><n>### Input 1:There are a total of 20 students working at the bookstore. Each of them is working towards the goal of buying a new book. They would also like to be able to buy a book that will cost more than half of their daily income, but they want to spread their savings out equally. How old is the oldest student serving as the manager of the store?<n><n>### Response 1:<n>This one doesn't seem so bad.<n><n>### Response A: I see there has been 7 new employees since last Tuesday. Let's double that to 14 and half that by 4 for each shift so it's 44, and then I subtract each employee individually. This means there are a total of 14 employees. If the oldest employee makes about $150 per day, and $90 of it goes to rent, there's only about $60 for food per day after expenses. If you take out half of that, only $20 is left for each individual employee to spend on food, and if we split it evenly it only leaves each employee $10 per day to spend with the whole group. So... the oldest employee works part-time, maybe at McDonald's or something and the rest of their income comes from the bookstore....<n><n>### Response B: Let's say they all get pay of $34, which can be found among their 20 employees. If they want to make at least $40 per day, they need to get at least 2 other people to sell $40 in books. Well, that's $60! They're selling at least 4 books a day to make that amount.<n><n>### Input A:<n>Five years ago Josh's father started with 2,712 in his bank account and 175 in his piggy bank ($3,887 in total). Input:Mark has kangaroos, goats and 35 cows.  Kangaroons has 2 legs and goats have 4 legs.  What is the total number of the legs in his farm if he 3 times as many goats than kangaroons?<n>```<n>If he has 3 times the amount of goats as he has kangaroons, that means he has 2/3 the number total the amount of goats and cows.  Because he has 35 cows, you need to multiply the ratio of goats and kanguarous to cows.  So 2/3 x35 = 21.73<n>```<n><n>## 6.Input:Sarah, Mary, and Tua need to pay for a meal.  They decided to split the bill evenly.  However, they found that the cost of the food was $67 and they only got a coupon for $5  off, making the final bill $62.  How much does each person need contribute to the bill?  <n>Let's work this backwards to begin with:  We need to figure out how much did they each have to contribute to get down to $62.  So, Mary, Tuan, and Sarah had to add together and spend $105 between the three of them.  This means that each person needed to split $105 so $105 / 3 = $35.  But $35 / 3 = Mary $11.66, Tuan $11.61 and Sarah $11.73. <n>But Mary got a $5.00 coupon for $4 total and Sarah got a $6.00 coupon leaving the bill amount of $

How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>### Input:Where would you get a bass clarinet to take home? Choices:  A: orchestra B: school band C: music store D: opera house E: home<n><n>### Response:		A: orchestra<n><n>### Input A: How much would the bass clarinet cost if you were to buy it from the orchestra?<n><n>### Response A:  $183<n><n>### Input B: How much would the cost if you bought it from the music store?<n><n>### response B:  $205<n><n>###Input C: The owner of the school band gave 10% off and you bought a bass clarinet worth $250.<n><n>###Response C: $225

How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh‚Äôs mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>### Input:An electronics store had things damaged from the rain, where should these things be stored? Choices:  A: large city B: strip mall C: building D: shopping mall E: aquarium<n><n>### Response:		Input:A: large city<n><n>Answer: Choice A<n><n>**What happens here:**<n>Choices that don't represent a possibility are eliminated by the question.<n><n>## Detailed Explanation<n><n>**Input:** Choices:<n><n>* A: A large city<n>* B: A strip mall<n>* C: A building<n>* D: A shopping mall<n>* E: An aquarium<n><n>**Response:** Input: A: large city<n><n>**What happens:**<n>Choices are eliminated by the questions until a choice is left.<n><n>## References<n><n>[https://www.google.com/url?sa=t&amp;rct=j&amp;q=&amp;esrc=s&amp;source=web&amp;cd=5&amp;cad=rja&amp;uact=8&amp;ved=2ahUKEwjT1aeH5rP5AhVR-TgGHRZ-DzQFjAKegQIAxAB&amp;url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.learnstudy.net%2Fblog%2Fshort-answer-writing&amp;usg=AOvVaw3h364y3vQ3L-6ZpzGbXW6L]<n>

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh‚Äôs mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>### Input:What would release energy, but not mainly in your muscles? Choices:  A: vent B: think C: shouting D: work off E: exercise<n><n>### Response:		<n>> C. Shouting<n><n>### Input<n>> Sarah bought a notebook with 100 pages. 56 of those pages were double sided.  How many single sided pages were in the book if there were one blank left page on both odd and odd numbered pages?<n><n>### Response<n>> B. 26 + 26 = 52<n><n>### Input :<n>> Three friends, Derek, Alyssa, and Ben, shared $36 among themselves, and they each received the same amount of money. How much was each given?<n><n>### Output<n>> 36 divided by 3 = $12<n><n>### Instructions<n>> Find the values of m and n in the following table.<n><n>|M|N|<n><n>|---|---|---<n>|8|14|<n>|-1|0|<n>|-8|-5|<n><n>Answer: M = 8, N = 14<n><n>### Instuctions<n>> Find the first digit of the product of these numbers: <n><n>|m | n |<n><n>|---| ---|<n>|11  |13  |<n>| -1 |5 |<n>| -11  | -5  |<n><n>### Output:<n>> 1<n><n>### Instractions:<n>> You can answer one of the following questions.<n><n>Choose which question to answer.<n><n>> A: There are 12 boys in your school basketball team. There are 6 times as many girls than boys, and there are 20 boys in the choir. How many girls are there in the choir?B: 12 girlsC: 60 girls<n><n>If you chose A, input this number 12 in m:<n><n>12*20/6 = 10<n>Therefore, m = 10<n>10/12 = 10/12. Therefore n =12<n>So the answer to this question is C.<n>60 girls<n><n>### Input Choice<n>> The number that comes next in the series 1, 2, 4, 8, __, 20, 40, __, 80, is:<n>a: 12<n>b: 16

Choices: A: a question B: a conversation C: a greeting D: a shout E: a way of saying hello<n><n>### Response:"What's going" in this scenario is this? Choices:"the weather","a fight between coworkers", "people's personal life", "people's opinions about something", "the latest news", "people's views on an event or issue"<n><n>### Input-<n>A friend asked her friend: "Where's Anna going from here?"<n><n>### Response-<n>A: To the zoo.<n><n>### Input"Here" was Anna's home. This made the friend think that Anna was moving to another place because she was going to this place. If Anna really wasn't going anywhere but just going to the zoo on a field trip, her question would make little sense. But if Anna were going far away like to China, Canada, or another country on another continent this is not this question.<n><n>##Input:Choose one of the following statements as your response.<n><n>##Response:<n>The car's owner says that he/she only drives the car on Sundays.<n>

If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>### Input:Where might a yard be tiny? If 6 students is all Ms. Green needs to feel comfortable with her class size, what is the minimum number of students Ms. Brown would need?<n><n>### Response  :90<n><n>### Input : The sum of 4 numbers is 68. If one of the numbers is decreased by 9 and another number is increased by 19, what is the new sum?<n><n>### Demostration: The sum of 4 number is 68. It means 68 = 4 x 17.<n><n>The first number is:  (x - 9) = 68 - 69 = (27 - 19) = 0<n><n>The second number is: (x + 19) = (69 + 19)<n><n>The sum:<n>```<n>4x = 68<n>x = 17<n>```<n>```<n>4(17) = 68<n><n>```<n><n>The sum of 4 numbers: 68<n><n>When x is decreased by 19, the new number is:  (27 - 9) = x = 17 <n><n>When x is increased by 17 the new number is: (17 + x) = (69 - 19)<n>= 40 <n>Then the sum is x + 40 = 17+40 = 57<n><n>### Input:: 70 students are assigned to 6 rooms. If one more room is needed, how many students would each room need?<n><n>## : 10<n><n>###Input:: In 25 minutes 8 minutes are required to drive a car 12 miles. How long to drive 24 miles?<n>

The old bowling recored is a total of 110,000 points. Each team has 5 players and there are 25 games in the season. Through 23 games, the team has scored 9,600 points. The team needed to only get 16 points less than the average so the new average would be 129.4.<n><n>## Demo Explanation<n>### Instruction 3<n><n>## Instruction: Answer each question below.<n><n>Write a response that completes the request. **Your responses should be in the form of mathematical sentences.**<n><n><n>Input:<n>A group of friends are sharing a large chocolate cake.<n>One third of the cake is left for each friend to eat. If there are 2 grams of sugar in every flake, then what is the mass of sugar in one box that holds 1/2 the square foot of flakes?<n><n>### Response<n>There are 1600 grams of sugar in the flakes. One ounce of sugar is 28.3495 grams. So 1 gram of sugar is 0.03596 ounces. Therefore, there are 4794.52216 grams of sugar in 31 ouncels of cornflakes.

How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>### Input:Where are all participants likely to need sports equipment? Choices:  A: dicks sporting goods B: sporting event C: mall D: sears E: sporting goods store<n><n>### Response:		B<n><n>### Instructions:The students want to write down all possible words that use the vowels in the word "Miracle". How many possible words can they develop using the vowels in this word.<n>### Output:12 words<n>### Input:An engineer creates a rectangular box using a meter and a half of board using no more than 50% of the board. What are the dimensions of the longest sides of the box, if the total length of the board is 8 meters.<n><n>### Output:300 m 500 m 600 m 700 m and 985 m<n>### Input:Nine students in a class have more than one toy. 14 students in a class have at least one toy. How many students in that class have only one toy?<n><n>### Output:"The group of students who have only one toy is 14 - (9 + 14) = 14 - 23 = 9"

Choices:  A: competition B: blood C: wins D: medals E: erections<n><n>### Response:		The man was playfuly wrestling with a woman.<n>#### He was enamored with her.<n>##### "Choices:"<n><n>- Choice A: competition: The choice "competition" is incorrect because competition is the action of competing. Enamored is a passive and an instance of the verb used in the sentence is "He was enamored with."  It should actually be "She was enamored with him."<n><n>- Choice B: blood: Choice "B" has the correct spelling.<n><n>- Choice C: wins: The choice "wins" is incorrect because it is a noun in a question. Nouns do not ask questions, only verbs.<n><n>- Choices D, E: Erections: "Erections" is a noun and it is not a verb, and cannot be changed into one so it is not an answer.<n><n>### Input:"Dark Knight Rises" was the best movie I've seen this month.  Its rating was "10/10".  How many stars would you give it?<n><n>### Response:"Dark Knight Rise is the best movie I'm seen this month, it's ratings 10/10. How many stars would give it?"<n>#### "Dark Knight Rise" is incorrect because there is an apostrophe in the film title.<n><n>#### The response should be written in full sentences (e.g., "Dark Knight Rises," was the best movie I saw this month, with an excellent 10/1o rating), and there is a space between "stars" and ".  Please correct the error.<n>

She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh‚Äôs mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>### Input:The college kids weren't known for their apartment decor choices, they used a folding chair inside their what? Choices:  A: bathroom B: closet C: school D: room E: church<n><n>### Response:		<n>"A"<n><n>#### Why It's Right:<n>A. They used a folding chair in their bathroom and they weren't known to be very clean.<n><n>#### Why It Might Be Wrong:<n>A. It's impossible that a person used a folding chair as their bed.<n><n>### Input; There is a town called Happy where the average age of the population is 150 years. A town called Sad has an average age of 68 years. The town of Happy was founded in what year?<n><n>### Response<n><n>"22 AD"<n><n>### Why It's Right<n><n>A. If the average age is 150 and then divided by.3 would be 150/0.3 which is 500.<n><n>### Why Is It May Be Wrong<n><n>It's a 9069.<n><n>### <n><n>### 3.2 How do I format the problem statement?<n><n>Make the question more clear and easier for the student or anyone who may not understand. Sometimes we like our questions a certain way we may not realize they may not be the best way. Just because our question is not worded as what we believe does not mean the student did not understand our question.<n><n>## 3.3 What is the best way to give examples?<n><n>Keep it simple or you may not get the best answers.<n><n>## 4.1 What is the best way that I can ask for clarification?<n><n>First, before jumping to a conclusion, ask multiple people the same question. Have your student explain their answer to someone else or in group of students, this could help avoid some misunderstanding and could help you learn to speak it out differently the next time. If you find that your student keeps answering the wrong question, you can say, I‚Äôm not sure I got what your saying could you explain in a different way?<n><n>## 4 Questions<n><n>0.<n>### <n>1.<n>### 0.0<n>2.<n>### 1.0<n>3.<n>### 2.0<n>4.<n>### 3: You have 4 apples and 2 peaches. You are eating one apple a day and a peach every other day. How many days will you have to eat peaches

He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. Which of the following phrases does it contain? Choices A: The phrase he is referring to B: The phrase being discussed C: The phrase you are reading D: A phrase from Einstein<n><n>### Response<n>```shell<n>echo B<n>```<n><n>## 648<n><n>### Instructions:<n><n>Write 2 lines.  The first should read `echo` and the second: `echo `, then enter the 2 lines and press enter.<n><n>### <n><n>### Response :<n><n>```shell<n>echo<n>echo<n>```<n>### Instrucciones: <n><n>En una sola l√≠nea o espacio, escriba el comando `echo`, luego ingr√≠e `cat`<n>y luego ingr√≠e  `echo`, luego presione enter<n><n>### Respuesta:<n><n>```shell<n>cat<n>echo<n>```<n><n>## #6539<n><n>### Informat: Write two lines. The first should read  `echo`  and the second: `cat` <n><n>###  Instrucciones:  Incorparre en este espacio de tiempo un  sistema de archivos <n><n>### Respuestas:<n><n>```shell <n>echo<n>echo cat<n> ```<n><n>## #6730<n><n>#### Instrucciones<n>Write 4 lines.<n><n>#### Respuesta<n><n>```shell<n>1.echo <n>2.cat <n>```<n><n>## Instrucciones: Write two lines. Create a conditional logic to ask the user the answer to a few questions<n><n>### Response<n><n><n><details><summary><strong>Input</strong> Questions: </summary><n>The first question was about if they like the job they currently have then answer True or False.<n>The second question was about do they like helping people then they will again answer True or False.The third and final question was they have ever participated in any anti government protest then just a Yes or No.<n><n></details><details><summary><strong><strong>Answer</strong></summary><summary><strong> Question 1: </strong></summary><n>If I like my job:TrueFalse<n><n>If I want to change something:TrueFalse<n><n><n></details><h2>Code</h2><n><n>```javascript<n>if(answer == true){<n>    answer2 = getPrompt("Should you change your job or start a business of your own?");<n>}<n>else{<n>    answer2 = "you should change your job";<n>}<n>```<n><n></details><n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh‚Äôs mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>### Input:What would form on your feet, if you were jogging all day? Choices:  A: heart attacks B: hole in your socks C: exhaustion D: shortness of breath E: blisters<n><n>### Response:		D:  shortness of breath<n><n>### Challenge:<n>

Choices:  A: farm B: ancient rome C: history book D: poor countries E: plantation<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Demographics:<n><n>1. Suggested to use 'A' for each choice, it looks like an easy choice but that's the key thing.<n>1. 4 of the answers have similar qualities in them, they are based around 'A', in this case they are also 'Rome', 'Book' and 'poor countries'.<n>1. Look for qualities that link to 'A' because in that case, 'D' is a lot simpler.<n><n>### Inputs<n><n><n>### Input 1:Jenn and Adam like chess. Jenn and Adam have a 9 day difference. At the end of Day 1, Adam has played twice as many turns as Jenn. At the end of day 9, who‚Äôs ahead at the end of Day 9?<n><n>### Demand: At the end of day one.<n><n>### Response 1: Adam<n><n>### Response Demonstration: At the end of Day one Adam will have played twice as many games. Therefore, he will have 2 more games than Jenn. So, he is ahead after day one.<n><n>Input 2: A car had a 1/4 tank. It was full after filling for 20 dollars. 10 liters of gas was used every week. What was the cost of gas?<n><n>Output: At first we fill up 1/4 of a tank.<n><n>So, 1/4 X 20 dollars equals 5 dollars.<n><n>Next, we spent 7 additional dollars every week.<n><n>So we spend...<n><n>(1/4 + (7/8)) X 5 dollars equals 35 dollars<n><n>### Answer<n><n>### Input3:<n><n>### AnswerDemonstration:<n><n>I wrote this answer: We fill up 1/8 of our tank.<n><n>A full tank of gas is 20 liters.<n><n>So, after filling for 2 dollars, we spent 7 more dollars the very next week.<n><n>Since we spend...<n><n><n>### 7 more dollars...<n><n>(1.25 X 7 dollars) equals 7.5 dollars.<n><n>And so, we spent a total of 1.50 dollars EVERY week.<n><n><n>So, we spent $107.5

How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>### Input:What could fighting inflation cause if it is not successful? Choices:  A: problems B: not noticeable C: deflation D: economic instability E: eat cake<n><n>### Response:		Inflation could cause not noticeable and economic instability.<n><n>### Outcome:No one wanted to help the guy with a problem when he was lost because he was not friendly and did not greet people. He got on a flight alone to travel back home. I believe the outcome would be very different if he had greeted people, and also, if he acted friendly.<n><n>### Inputs:What if the pilot was not paying attention?<n><n>### Response:{The guy could have been a good pilot, and also not pay attention.}<n><n>### Outcomes:<n><n>- The plane could have crashed.<n>- The plane could not have crashed.<n><n>### The pilot could have stopped paying attention when he crashed the plane. The pilot can stop when he got scared, if he didn't he might crash.<n><n>### Response to Outcomes:<n><n>The chances of having positive is greater than having a negative outcome of the pilot's lack of attention. The chance of a negative outcome is greater than having a positive outcome.<n><n>### Comments:<n><n>Not a lot of effort put into the assignment

He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. Alyssa is on the list to invite 9 people to the party, but she cannot invite friends on the list. She can invite family or friends, but she cannot invites any friends on the list. How many people will she invite to the party?"<n><n>### Response:"It will be hard to invite only 9 people because there are a lot of possibilities."<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following multiple option question.<n><n>##  Problem description:Create a solution program to handle data<n><n>Problem type: Programming, Multiple-choice<n><n>Language: Python<n><n>Required language features: None<n><n><n>Test cases:<n><n>### Instruption: The number of people who attended the party is 4 less than the number of people invited.<n><n>### Solutions:<n>* If you invite 9 people, there are 4 options left to choose:<n>** 5, 4, 3, and 2<n><n>* If there are five options left to choose. The most of the people attend the party with.<n><n>* Or you can use math.<n><n>* We can add it all together:<n><n>* The total number of attendees = 46<n><n>* The total numbers of people invited/attending = attendee count / inviting count<n><n>* Therefore,<n><n>* The number of people invited = 52

Heather decides to spend $10 on a book, $5 on another book, and uses up the rest of her money on a pencil. How many books did Heather buy?<n><n>###Response:<n>She bought 1 and 1/3 books.<n><n>###Instruction:Answer questions in complete sentences.<n><n>###Ques:How much money did Heather have left over<n><n>###After reading the following statement, choose the response that makes sense.<n><n>###Statement:If Josh saves $50 this year, he will have $247 at the end of the year because he is earning 2 dollars interest per year.<n>1:Choices:A: Josh should save $100 to increase the amount saved.<n>B: Savings is already enough.<n>C: $247 is a bad number.<n><n>###Correct Respone:A: Josh should not save $50 because it does not increase the amount saved.  Instead, He should save $10 or $60 to increase the amount of saved money in the account.<n>

How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. Choices: 1: 88 2: 42 3: 44 4: 88<n><n>### Response<n>If there are 44 cubicles and there are 5 people, the answer is 88.<n><n>### InputSituation<n>If there are two chairs are sitting in one cubicle room the total amount of chairs is 16. What is the number of the chairs? Choices: 2: 16 3: 8 4: 10 5: 8<n>- A is wrong. Because we only have info that there are two chairs<n>- B is wrong, because if there were two chairs sitting in the room the answer would be 2 but there are 8<n>- and E is wrong because the answer should be 10 and not 8<n><n>### Answer<n>In the room there are 8 chairs<n><n>### Input Situation<n><n>The number of employees in the room is 10. The room is 80 meters long and 24 meters wide. What is the percentage of the total distance occupied by the room? Choices: 4: 60% 5: 20% 6: 35% 7: 80%<n>- A is the answer<n><n>### Input <n>There are 87 chairs a meeting room and there are 24 people. If each chair is a used by a person how many chairs need to be taken out? He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>### Input:Sam left his muddy shoes in the entryway. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>### Input:What might a satisfied person do? Choices:  A: board ship B: grocery shop C: cross street D: feel happy E: shout at<n><n>### Response:		<n><n><n>---<n><n>### Instructions: Answer the following multiple choice question by clicking the Choice:<n><n><n><n>If you have any questions about this challenge feel free to post them on <https://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/leetcode><n>Github: <https://github.com/pig-zhao/leetcode> <https://github.h3sj2/pig-z4n-leetcode><n><n>If you are new to leetcode this is a great website to practice coding interviews! How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh‚Äôs mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>### Input:If I wanted to store my chess pawn when I wasn't using it, what would be a good place for that? They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>### Input:If I have a forgiving attitude toward someone, what do they receive? Choices:  A: redemption B: isolation C: absolution D: great relief E: feel better<n><n>### Response:		Choice A<n>### Instructions:Answer the question as completely as possible. <n>### My thoughts: I think that if someone is forgiving and have a forgiving attitude with them, then they will receive redemption and feel better for them since that they are forgiven and have given forgiveness.<n><n>### Input : A girl had two chairs  in her house. She also had an armchair  that was not in her house. She had a bed in her backyard but she  didn't realize that there was a chair under it.  She  only had one house key.  She sat on both chairs and then put  her purse in the armchair. How  many chairs did she have at the end?<n><n>### Response : It is hard to understand how she has an arm chair under the bed that she does not realize that there was a second chair there. That is why I get confused on how to solve it. My guess would be she still would have two chairs and still have only one house key.<n><n>### My Question: What does the code mean to go from a 4 to a 3? If I am coding an asterisk I would not code to 3 then back to the 4. <n><n>### Instruzioni:Write on a separate sheet of paper, a series of six numbers (1-6). Next to each number write the mathematical addition, each of the two adjacent numbers. (2 + 3 = 5 ; 3 +5 = 8 ; 4 + 6 = 10.  Do not repeat a set of numbers. The answer is found by adding the first to the third, the second to the fourth and the first to the last.<n><n>### Risposta: 1 + 5 = 6 ; 2 + 6 = 8 ; 3 + 5 = 8 ;4 + 4 = 8 <n>### Codice:<n><n>### Instrazione:In the list 1: What was the last digit of the sum of the last digit and the sum of the third last digit and the sum 2 of the last digit and last digit summed four times?<n>### Risposta : 9<n><n>### Instrizione:In the list of 2: 1) What was the sum of the first number, the second number

The remaining 13 subjects did not have a decreased strength as they ate 15 or more grams of per meal protein.  All test subjects were given the same dietary guidelines and did not receive any additional exercise or training advice in addition to their protein intake strategy. I define a function<n>2. I call the function and pass it the parameter x.<n>3. I define the function inside a loop and increase the number of calls until it reaches the total number.<n>4. The inner loop calls the function until it reaches the total amount the function is supposed to be called for.<n>5. The outer loop calls the inner loop until it reaches the total parameter. <n>6. I can call the inner function as many time as I pass, it's only depending on the parameter.<n><n>### Inputs: This is a question from chapter 9. 5 different people will attend a lecture and each of them has a different amount. Choose the smallest amount.<n><n>### Answer<n>A is the smallest amount.<n>In fact,<n>The smallest amount, multiplied by 5, is: (60/5) * 5 = 120<n>The least amount is (60 + 7) => (67) => 67.<n>If you multiply it by (5 - 7), you'll get 39.  <n><n>The smallest amount after multiplying by 5 = 39<n><n>### Input <n>This is from chapter 9.<n>The total is (25 x 2 + 15 x 7 + 20 x 3) => 6815.<n>

Choices:  A: own home B: old england C: new hampshire D: coffin E: denmark<n><n>### Response:		<n>*If you own a small dog, it is likely you live in England so you likely own a large home.<n>* New hampshire is a state of the U.S. so if you are lost it is likely in America, in a den or coffin!<n>*New England is part of the United States so most likely it is in America.<n>* Denmark is part of Europe so you probably are not in Denmark.<n>*Because "Coffin" starts with "C" and "Small Dog" starts with "S" which is how letters are sorted.<n>*Because it must be in new england or old england but new england is part of the united states.<n><br><br><n><n>## 1.Write to the following prompts.<n><n>1. When you think about your daily activities, you notice that most of them occur as a result of an action.  When you get up in the morning, you go to the bathroom, brush your teeth, grab your backpack, etc.  When taking a shower or doing chores, you are performing an action. <n><n>Write two paragraphs about yourself in which you describe at least two specific actions or activities you partake in on a regular basis, how you accomplish each, and the result or consequences that accompany those actions or activities. <n><n>2. It is difficult to argue that a person in a third world country is lesser for suffering as a result of the lack of basic necessities like shelter, clothing, clean water, medicine, and education.  This argument, also known as the "luck" argument, is one of the most common arguments for those who seek to defend poverty as "deserved" for the "poor."  The logical fallacy in that argument is to blame poverty on the "bad luck" of being born poor - as if the lack of necessities that makes someone poor were the product of no action by the individual him or herself. <n><n>In two paragraphs, explain why it is illogical to conclude that poverty is "deserved," how bad luck arguments can be countered, and what steps you would take to convince an individual living in poverty and who suffers the consequences as a result of their inability to secure necessities that their situation is not their fault. <n><n>3. Your family is leaving the United States to

Choices:  A: walmart B: loft C: house D: home depot E: kitchen<n><n>### Response:		Answer E: kitchen<n><n>Comment: Question 3 can be answered differently. You have to find the number of legs left, so you need to subtract the animals without legs (goats) to get a remaining number of legs.<n><n>Example:<n>Number of goats (1 goats = 4 legs): 4 + 3 = 7<n>Number of kangaroos (2 legs): 23 - 3 = 20<n>Total legs remaining = 20 + 7 = 27 legs.<n><n>Answer for a biology quiz can be changed to: Max did 4/6 of his homework in biology.<n><n>Answer for math (quiz 2): Max did 8/12 of his homework in geometry, he spent 17/20 seconds on math homework.<n><n>There are some other errors I have found which I have fixed, but I am not sure if they are correct. You can only select 1 choice per question. The questions and choices are in the table below.")<n>    print("I am the question. Please answer me: ")<n>    print("Q1:",<n>          question("What is the greatest common factor of 24 and 36?", "The GREATEST common factor of 2 and 5 is 1. The LARGEST common factor of 32 and 24 is 16."<n>                  "A common factor is a number that is a factor of two or more numbers.", "A common factor is always less than the greatest or largest common factor."),<n>          choice("A", "B", "C", "D", "E"),<n>          choice_id = "Q1"<n>          )<n><n>    print("Q2:", question(<n>          "The quotient for 2/3 x 4/5 is:",<n>
