The seasons of this show revolved around characters finding themselves and changing. The relationships in this show range from a romantic interest, to a mother and daughter relationship. Through each new character's storyline, the characters we loved began to crumble and the viewer was lead to hate each new character we were introduced to. The viewer began to feel like we were being thrown into a new story each time we turned onto the television. This show left me with the question we're watching the same story over and over again, or are we following a new storyline? <n><n>---<n>##### If we continue to watch the show and follow the characters that don't seem to change or grow throughout their time in the show, we are able to view as the same characters over and over again.<n>##### If we don't continue to watch the show, and we only stop and watch one or two episodes at a time to get the jist of this drama, we are able to follow the same story that is aired on TV.<n><n>### Challenge:Create another set of questions such as those from the above challenge.<n><n>**Questions for the Reader**<n><n>**Write a response to the above tasks.**<n>

East coast areas such as Florida that are found in the same ocean as another major city like Calgary means the area is found in the same ocean on the eastern side.  <n><n>In this case, we learn more about the geography of North America and the United States as it is surrounded by a body of water. Canada and the United States are part of the US and North America.<n><n>Answers:<n>- A: florida - False<n>- B: denmark - False<n>- C: united states - True<n>- D: map - False<n>- E: california - False<n><n>### Input(Continued):East coast areas such  as Florida are found where:C: United statesD: California<n>E: Map<n>F: Denmark<n>G: Florida<n>A: A&C; B; D; E: Florida<n><n>### Answer: D<n><n>- A, and E: False answers<n>- B, C, and G: True answers<n><n>### Instructons:<n><n>As aforementioned, Florida is a state in the united states that is found in the Atlantic Ocean on the eastern side. <n><n>As aforesaid, the answer to the question is that Florida is found in the United States of North America which is surrounded by waters on it's western side.

I don't know if that's the objective of fighting inflation, so I think we should be careful with what we do when we fight inflation.<n>

For example, the value 5 could be represented by the numbers -2, 6 or 7.<n><n>Thus the number on the line represents the representation of the value by the number.  So the two numbers on the line represent the two names used to represent the value.<n><n>The question is:<n><n>What about a person - and their personality - is represented by more than one number?<n><n>For example, the two numbers above represent the personality of a child.  What would be the most common numbers that a personality could be represented by?<n><n>Choose the set that contains the more common numbers.<n><n>Output:  the same<n>\<n>\<n>Input:<n><n>Input a value<n><n>2 or -3<n><n>Output:  -3 2<n>\<n>\<n>\<n> \<n>\<n>\<n>Output:<n><n>Input:<n><n>Output:<n><n>Choose the best answer.<n>\<n>\<n>1 or 0<n><n>Choice:<n><n>Input: the same<n>\<n>  \<n>\<n>\  <n>\  <n>Output: 0<n>\<n>\<n>6 or 9<n><n> \<n>\<n>6 or -5<n><n>\<n>  \ -6 or 11  <n>\<n>  \  12\<n>\<n> \  5<n>\<n><n> Choice:<n>\<n>  \ \<n>21<n><n> \<n>  \<n>72<n><n>Output: 36<n><n>Choice:<n>\<n> \<n>64<n><n>Output:<n>

The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>### Input:Where must one wear a white shoe? People go there to have their hair cut<n><n>### Solution B:<n><n>### Question:<n>### Solution:<n>There are so many ways to solve this problem however one of the ways is by using the given choices that are already been explained with explanation above, as shown on diagram.<n><n>### Input<n>### Solution:You need the following steps to solve the question given: 1.Identifying the number of strawberries in the given set 2.counting the required strawberries for each given cup 3.summing the all numbers up from step 2 <n>**Step 1**<n>| Number of Strawberries  | Total Number of Strawberies  |<n>|:-----------------------:|:-------------------------:|<n>|   3 large ones    |0 |<n>|   4 medium ones    |4 5\*\*3= 10 15\*\*4= 60  |<n>|   0 small ones    | -95-|<n><n>**Step 2**<n><n>| Cup Number|Required Quantity|<n><n>|:-----------:|-----------------:|<n><n>|**1**|3 medium  | |<n><n>|**2**| 3 medium |7|<n><n>|**3**| 0 medium | -6|<n><n>|**4**|1 medium | -4|<n><n>**Step3**<n><n>15+16 + -95 - 60+ -195<n><n>**Step 4**<n><n>18+ 4 = 22<n><n>**Step 5**<n><n>18*2 = 36<n><n>**Step 6**<n><n>36 -36 = 0<n><n>**Step 7**<n><n>Number of strawberries remaining = 0<n><n><n>### Solution For Second Question<n><n>### Question<n><n>### Solution<n><n>### Input For The Second Solution<n>The questions are simple questions for this.<n><n>### Solution of 1st Question<n><n>### Input for the First Question<n>The input for the questions given below:<n><n>Input the total amount of allowance given to each student.<n><n>The method to solve the problem:<n>

How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh‚Äôs mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>### Input:Where is microphone boom likely to be used to record an album? Choices:  A: radio station B: recording studio C: concert D: tv studio E: new york<n><n>### Response:		A radio station.<n>

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh‚Äôs mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>### Input:Bob thought that his Pokemon cards were common and worthless, but he was wrong about them. If the farm sells all their produce individually, how many boxes of corn can you buy for $500 total?<n>```<n>import static java.lang.Math.*;<n>public class Solution48 {<n>    public int solution (int[] input) {<n>        int corn = 0, lettuce = 0, apples = 0, peaches = 0, oranges = 0, strawberries = 0, boxes = 0;<n>        int inputSum = 0, moneyAmount = 0, cornAmount = 0, totalAmount = 0, money = 1000;<n>        for (int i : input) {<n>        // int inputSum = 20;<n>                // int moneyAmount = input.length, input[], inputSum, money, moneyAmount, cornAmount, totalAmount, money = 1;<n>                cornAmount += pow(corn, cornAmount);<n>                moneyAmount += pow((int)money, moneyAmount);<n>                totalAmount += pow(totalAmount, totalAmount);<n>                int money = 600

How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. Otherwise she should buy the bracelet.<n><n>### Example Input<n>Mary is $5.00 short of the shirt. What should Mary do?<n>Answer: She should buy the bracele.<n><n>### Description<n>This question is an example for which a student should write a program. <n><n>### Problem description<n>The question is asking where the student went if he used a "parking lot near a roller<n>coaster." Choices:<n>1.  Nine<n>2.  Three<n>3.  None<n>4.  28<n>5.  335<n>6.  There is no information that would allow us to answer.<n><n>## Question:<n>What did the girl eat? What do you know about her?<n><n>## Solution:<n>  * I don't know the right answer but I know that she ate a peach by multiplying once, and she ate an apple by multiplying four times. She's probably a mathematician or just a very experienced number-manipulator.<n>  * I can tell that only two of these statements are true,  and so I know she didn't eat a muffin and probably not a cookie.<n><n>## Question : What did the girl ate? What do you know?<n><n>## Solution :<n>  * First I tried the first step, the girl ate the apple. That was an incorrect step, so I tried the next most obvious thing since it's the first number she saw and it makes very little sense to choose a number like 5 or 6 because she has to multiply it at least once to be able to eat the apple. So I chose the apple and she ate it at some point.<n>  * Then I chose the banana. This time it made absolutely no sense to just pick the next number since I already knew that she is actually eating something and not just picking a random number. So I choose the next two numbers and she ate the banana at some point.<n><n>## Questions<n><n>### What is the greatest?<n><n>### Answer<n><n>16<n>

It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>### Input:What is a place that could have hundreds of sporting goods store? Choices:  A: buy athletic equipment B: city C: espn D: town E: jerseys<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>Buy Athletic Equipment is a place that could of hundred of sporting goods store.<n><n>### Additional Question:<n>What do you think will be the toughest question on the test?<n><n>### Assessment:<n><n>- Was the test easy or difficult?<n><n>### Add Comment:<n>Your comment

How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh‚Äôs mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>### Input:What cuisine is joked about eating small dogs? This was $10 that her parent paid her for mowing the lawn.<n><n>- The number of stickers Mary is left with is 44<n>- 44 - (3 * 1 = 3) = 41<n>- 41 - 10 = 31<n>- 31 - (7 * 2) = 6<n>- 6 = Total stickers she needs to earn before she can buy the bike<n><n><div class="question-answer"><n><div class="hint"><i>Sarah, Mary, Tuan decided to go the restaurant for a mea. It is also the smallest 2-digit prime when the sum of its digits is a prime also. All prime numbers beginning with 3 do not exist. So the smallest prime that begins with 3 does not exist. What is this number?<n>Answer: <n><n>### Instruct:What comes at the end of this sequence?54,33,12,3<n>Answer: 66<n><n>### Instction:<n>The 786 is such a important number. It's the only three digit number that has the numbers of the Fibonacci sequence in reverse in its digits. What‚Äôs this number‚Äôs value?<n>Answer: 967<n><n>### Instreact:It's such a special number. What is the number?<n>Answer: **08253<n>

How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. Choices:  A: wrong B: death of C: bad D: negative E: evil<n><n>### Response:		<n>**A: Wrong** is the response to the question.<n><n>## Task:Implement the following class:<n><n>MyName is Jon and I am giving away an old bike I no longer use. I will let anyone use the bike any time they need it. The bike is a 20-speed with 42 cm tires. The bike is in good condition but I encourage users to bring it back in good working condition.<n>```<n>public class OldBike {<n>	private String name;<n>	private int tireSizeInCM;<n>}<n>```<n>This class maintains information about the bike.<n><n>- **name** - Jon's nickname<n>- **tireSizeInCM** - the tire size in centimeters<n><n>The class is used to store bike information.<n><n>Give an object to your program from the list below.<n><n>- **Jon**: Jon lives in Austin.<n>	- **nickName = Jon**<n>	- **bike = OldBike**<n>		- **name = Jon**<n>		-   **tireSizeInCm = 42**<n>	<n>- **Tran**: Tran is Jon's friend.<n>	- **name = Tran**<n>	- **bikes = [Jon's bike]**<n>	<n>Use getters and setters to allow user input of an object name and the tire size in cm. Use these parameters to get the object's name and tire size in cm, if the object exists. Print the object's name to the screen.<n><n>The bike's tire size cannot be more that `500`cm or less than `140`cm.<n>

Which of these is true according to the passage? Choices: 1: The pole was made of buses 2: The pole was bent 3: The pole was not made of buses 4: The bus was bent 5: The bus hit the pole<n><n>### Response<n>The answer is D. The pole was made of iron and the bus crashed into it.  There is no way the pole was made of bus or be bent.<n><n>### The instructions:<n>Pick the best answer from the options available. Complete the following table by picking the best answer from the choices provided. <n><n>### Demand: A man and a woman are playing. The man has a coin with two sides, heads and tails, which he is using in a game. There is a box between them. Each turn the man selects one face of the coin behind his back and shows the other player. If it is heads, then the man puts the coin in the box. If tails, then the man puts his finger behind the box.<n>On a turn, the woman has the right to make one question to determine whether the man has put the coin in the box or his finger behind the box?  What is the best response option?<n><n>### Response option B.<n><n>### Why is the answer not option A. The person would get both side of the coin which indicates the option A is not the best answer.<n><n>### What if the person answer the option A.The coin would only show once, so the player cannot give the best answer.<n>### Why is option C the best choice?  It is the only option that is independent of what the player did for the previous questions.<n><n>### Which of these combinations would never be seen? Choices:  B: only white  C: only red and white  D: blue white and red  E: red and blue  F: only blue and white.<n><n>### Response Options D<n><n>### Explain why the answer is not C.  The combination

Choices a: questions b: disputes c: denies d: contradicts e: refuses<n><n>Output: The correct response is:  D<n><n>### Explanation:<n>If an applicant does not provide a reference, the confirmation of that reference will fail. This is because that applicant is essentially denying giving them an accurate reference.<n>

What did your code print?<n><n>---<n><n>### Democratization for Mental Health<n><n>As a health care company, SAMHSA‚Äôs efforts to democratize mental health are intended to help communities, tribes, and governments develop and refine strategies and models to reach those with mental health conditions and those impacting others. SAMHSA‚ÄôS efforts aim to support and promote the following: equitable access to mental health services and training, the development of integrated approaches, and supportive policy changes to improve access. SAMHSA is providing funding opportunities to support the [democratization of mental health strategies](https://www.samhsa.gov/programs/democratization-mental-health/democratization-training). More information about SAMHSA‚Äô‚Äôs efforts to demystify mental health and promote mental wellness, access to care, community support, and the inclusion of individuals with mental health needs in the community, can be found at [https://www.samhsagov/behavioral-health-wellness](https://www.psychologyservices.umass.edu/)<n><n>---<n><n>When you finish this activity, you will be able to:<n><n>- Demonstrate understanding of the SAMHSA guidelines of the democratization of mental health services.<n><n>- Explain ways the SAMHSA democratization of mental services can be supported.<n><n>---<n><n>#### Audience:<n><n>The intended audience for this course are employees in state health departments, community-based organizations, school districts, and other entities working to implement, evaluate and sustain evidence-based violence prevention programs, especially those designed to prevent youth violence and its proximate risk factors.<n><n>---<n>#### Course Overview<n><n>This course provides an overview of the SAMHDA strategies for promoting democratization for mental health.<n><n>---<n># SAMHSA Democratization for Ment Health Discussion<n><n><n>### Instructor Guidance<n><n>G

If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>### Input:Where would you stand in a line and need a coat if it is cold? Choices:  A: graph B: bank at noon C: good book D: post office E: bus stop<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>### Input<n>How many items does Cathy have and want to buy in a supermarket? Choices: 20 A: more than B: less than E: two <n><n>### Response<n><n>### Input <n>Five students are trying to solve the problem. Each of them is working with a different amount of time.  Choices:  A. 40 min B: 35 min C: 60 min D: 90 min E: 15 min F: 30 min  Question:<n>How many hours and 15 minutes does the whole group work together until they solve the math problem?<n><n>### Response Option 1 <n>We will let the first student start at 15 minutes later and we will tell him that in 40 minutes he should be done with the math problem. He starts to work and his counter counts down and he will get a notice to stop working 20 minutes before he should be completed.  He will work 30 minutes and if he is still on the problem then his counter resets. <n><n>### Option 2 <n>Option 1 can work fine since we have the number of minutes each student has.  But if we only work with the 40 minutes the group had before option 1 and option 2 then it would be a problem.<n><n>### Output<n>5. Option 2<n>Each student works with a different time span when they have to complete their part of the math problem.<n><n>We will let the work together until they solve their math problem.<n>The students will then need to show us the answer.<n><n>

Choices:  A: early morning B: day time C: night D: afternoon E: daytime<n><n>### Response:		<n>You need to choose Sarah's time leaving to answer the question you have been given.<n><n>Option 1: Sarah thought that she had been at home all evening. This means that she has a time she could leave.<n><n>Option 2: Sarah thought that she has been there all evening. This means she can also leave at night.<n><n>Option 3: Sarah thought that she's been home all evening. This meant that she could leave at any time.<n><n>Option 4: If you haven't been home all day then you don't even consider leaving. Sarah thought that she didn't have to come home at night to answer the question, so she leaves during the day.<n><n>Option 5: Sarah thought that she was home all night to answer the question. Therefore, there was nothing to tell her that she needed to come back. Sarah chose to leave during the day.<n>

But he thought it was wrong to have spend his whole life not knowing how to read when it was so easy to learn. So, it was the child's job to teach him.<n><n>### Question:<n>* A teacher is giving 4 test papers, each with 12 questions. What is the total number of questions given if there is no repetition of questions?<n>* Choices:  A. 144 B. 24 C. 48 D. 4<n><n>### Response<n>* It is the total number of the questions that the teachers are going to give to the students. So it is in fact 4 questions.<n>The answer is A.<n><n>### Input<n>* A man walks four, six, or eight blocks. Three more blocks than he has taken is 42. The total number of blocks the man walks is how many blocks if taken a minimum of five?<n>* How many blocks were on the first, second, and third legs respectively A. 2 3 2<n>* Four.<n>* One of the man's legs was six or eight blocks. If one of those legs was six, that gives us 6+5, or eleven that he's walked on.<n>* There are nine blocks in the remaining legs. The first leg was four, so we have 11+9.<n>* The answer is four.<n><n>### Subtask:<n>* Choice for question:<n>    * A. 2<n>    * B. 3<n>    * C. 4<n><n>* Number of blocks the man walcked on one leg A. 2<n>* Number of blocks in 2nd leg A. 3<n>* Number of blocks on 3rd leg A. 2.<n>

If Sara has 40 books, how many pencils and eraser does Sara have?<n>Solution: We know that Sara's pencils and erassers are two times more than books, so Sara's penzcils and erassers is 2x2=4. The question gives us that 40b+pencils and erasers is 40. We can conclude that total of all items is 2x40=80.<n><n>### Solution1: Incorrect: To solve it, you need to multiply by 3 and subtract 1 to result in -2 (so you would have -2 points).<n><n>Solution2: Correct: To solve it, first you need to double all the values, then you need to subtract the original one. Example: 11-10/11.<n><n>### Question: What do you have to do first to simplify: -3x1 / 4x2 or 2x5 / 10x7?<n>Solution: The first one is -3x1 /4x2= -3/4x2 is -3/16 which gives 1/2, which means you need to multiply your value by 2 and get the result is -3x2= -6. The second one we just need to do 2x5=10x7= 40.<n><n>## Conclusion

It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>### Input:Where should you find a school in? Choices:  A: residential neighborhood B: mosque C: every city D: prague E: community<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>Input:How old should children be to attend nursery school Choices:  A. 5 years B. 6 years old C. above 6 years D. under 5 years old <n><n>### Response:(under 6 years old or 5 years)<n><n>Input:Where is A‚Äôs room Choose one answer, there are 4 rooms:  A: kitchen B: living C: bathroom D: bedroom <n><n>### Input:(B)<n><n>Input:What is B‚Äôs last name Choices:  A.: Smith B C. Martin <n><n>### Answer:A<n><n>Input:(There is no way I will eat that) Choice: What does the girl prefer to eat A. pizza B. steak and potatoes C. chicken D. turkey<n><n>### Response D<n><n>Input:Should D be asked to take off his coat before he enters the room Choices:  A B C. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh‚Äôs mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>### Input:Where is a notebook often purchased? Choices:  A: bookstore B: backpack C: abraham lincoln's grave D: desktop E: classroom<n><n>### Response:		<n>Where:<n>Classroom<n><n>### Input :What is the longest river in North America? Choices: A: Amazon B: St. Lawrence C: Mississippi D: Saguenay E: Rhine<n><n>### Response :<n>What is the longest river?<n><n>### Input<n>What's the longest river?<n>

It began on July 11, 2017. A 16-hour cycle is counted. It begins on April 17, 2021. We know that the beginning dates of the two cycles coincide. How many years will it take in the second cycle for the two cycles to coincide again?<n><n>### Response B:<n>In each of the two cycles of 10 and 16 you must count from the day you began on each of these dates to determine the answer to the question.<n>The dates:  July 11,2017 to April 17,2021 are a year and a half in a cycle counting 10 cycles of the 10-years cycle so it will take 18 months of each cycle to have the two dates coincide again, so in total if you count from July 11, the date you began the 10 year cycle and then each date of the 10 years cycle, until April17, a date of the 16 year cycle, and then each date of 16 years cycle and continue to cycle to have a total

He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh‚Äôs mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>### Input:What could you buy in a bookstore? Choices:  A: carpeting B: magazines C: strip mall D: city E: applesauce<n><n>### Response:		 Choice B<n><n>### Instructions:Write a response that appropriately fills in the blanks.<n>Input: There are four different types of cheese in the ________ I want to make a grilled cheese sandwich.<n>Answer: _________________________________________________________________________________________________________<n><n>Input: My sister, ______ has a ________ and five sisters. She is the oldest.<n>Answer: ______________<n><n>Input: Which movie do you want to __________ tonight?<n>Answer: _________________<n><n>Input: I need some ice for my drink. Choices:  A: office building B: schoolroom C: library D: bedroom E: gym<n><n>### Response:		<n>##### If the choices were written the right way, we would have had "library" as the correct answer. <n>The letter "A" stands for "office building".<n><n>### Input : How long can you hold your breath underwater?<n><n>### Response :<n>In order to figure out how long they can hold their breath under water, one must have a formula for "decompression stops" or "decompression time." One can use, as a good example, the "deco stop" for an Apollo Spacecraft's return from space: the Apollo Mission Crew can hold their breath for a specified amount of time.  The Apollo Mission Crew would use this formula: "The time for which the Apollo Mission Craft Crew can stay submerged or pressurized, without suffering from the effects of high pressure and exposure to unfiltered air."<n><n>### Input <n>Two more of the animals are blue and red and have 4 and 2 legs. This is not correct because there are no animals with two legs in the first paragraph. The only animals mentioned have two legs.<n><n>### Input<n>#### The two lines below give information about a sale at a toy store. Line 1: Children, parents, and grandparents can receive a 10% discount. Line 2: Children can receive a free game if they bring in the box of a recently purchased toy and exchange it for another. What do grandparents need to do to receive a free gift?<n>##### The correct answer is the third option, "Give a grandchild at least 50 cents with the box after buying a toy." <n>The grandparents do not need to do anything to receive a free gift. The second line of the instruction states that children will receive a free game.  If grandparents' children have a toy, then the grandparents can receive the free gift for the children, who do not actually need to go to the store.<n><n>### A 3-digit number is evenly divided into three equal groups of three digits each. The sum of the second and third digits is 33. The middle digit is 6 greater than the first digit and the sum of the three digits is 78. What is the middle digit in the number?<n>Solution : There are 2 possible numbers that fit this problem

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh‚Äôs mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>### Input:Stopping being married to one another was a costly task, the lawyers and their what were astronomical? Choices:  A: free time B: pleasure C: get divorced D: legal fees E: being lonely<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>We think C - Get divorced<n><n>### Instructions:<n>Answers are provided for your reference.<n><n>#### [ ] 1. What is the first step in the process of using the PEMDAS order?<n><n>#### [ ] A) add<n>#### [ ] B) multiply<n>#### [ ] C) subtraction<n>#### [ ] D) division<n><n>#### [ ] B. multiply<n><n>#### [ ] D. division<n><n>#### [X] multiplication<n><n>#### [  ] E. multiplication / division<n><n>### Instagram comments are a great way to get feedback on your post.<n><n>### [ ] 1. Add up all the numbers in the list<n><n>### [15] 2. What is the difference between this number and 70?<n><n>### [ 9] 3. Write the equation that shows how to get the answer<n><n>### [3/4]<n><n>### X 3/4<n><n>### 1. Add your numbers<n><n>### 2. Subtract the smallest number from the largest number<n><n>### 3. Multiply answers to step 2 by 4<n><n>### [X] 4. You have 335 new yarn.<n><n>### How many skeins are in the box?<n><n>###<n><n>### 5. 20<n><n>###<n>### 6. How much more money does he have to save?<n><n>### 8. 33<n><n>### [5-6] 7. How many pages of her journal does Mary have left?<n><n>### The stickers she used on one page was three and then 7 to each other<n>#### [ ] The extra sticker for the cover and six sticker for the journal cover<n>#### [ ] seven stickers<n><n>### 9. How many legs does Mark's animals have?<n><n>### K = 2 and G = 4<n><n>## # = 322<n>###<n>## [15, 32, 90, 208, 341]<n><n>###<n>#### [ ] A 80<n><n>### He needs to earn 6 more dollars to break the league record.<n><n>## # = $334

She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh‚Äôs mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>### Input:What will happen if you are successful when committing suicide? First use a while loop to iterate on a string variable. <n>2. while(True) print(char)<n>2. use if statement to if the character is uppercase and lowercase.<n>  <n>1. if uppercase, use for loop to iterate uppercase<n>2. if lowercase, use for loop again but this time iterate with lowercase <n>3. break when loop does not come across any letter or character in a string<n>4. use function which will return true if the alphabet is in character letter. <n><n>1. If not, use elif statement to show if you have reached end of the alphabet or any character.

Which was larger?<n><n>### Response B:<n><n>Answer B: Kelly<n><n>### Input B:There are two coins in the vault. They each are either a green or a blue dime. If they are different, then one is a blue dime; the other is a green dime. If they're both the same, then they are both green dimes. Is the total value of these two coins at least $0.25? If it is not $0.25, do the coins add up to the same $0.25 as each other?<n><n>### Instructions C:Analyze the following code and select the most accurate response.<n><n>```Java<n>public void hello() {<n>    System.out.println("Hello!");<n>    System.out<n>       .println("This is a Java Program");<n>}<n>```<n><n>### Instrument D:<n><n>>   <pre>   #   1:  37775  2:  11627  3:  64451  4:  54721  5:  18363</pre><n><n>```C++<n>#include <iostream><n>#include <vector><n><n>using namespace std;<n><n>class Solution<n>{<n>    static int getDigit(int n, char c)<n>    {<n>        int num = n * pow(c - '0', n - 1);<n>        return num;<n>    }<n><n>    public:<n>    int findDigitSum(int n, vector<char> nums)<n>    {<n>       for (int i = 0; i < nums.size(); i++)<n>            n += nums[i];<n>                      <n>        return n;<n>    }<n>};<n>```<n><n>## Explanation<n><n>### Instructor's explanation:<n><n>Answer A) Supermarket.<n><n>### Student response A:<n><n>### Instraction B)<n><n>### Student's response to the following code:<n><n>```Java<n>import java.util.Scanner;<n>public class SumTwoNumbers {<n>    public static int sum(

Choices:  A: large city B: seattle C: curry D: clothing E: reservation<n><n>### Response:		John would order curry if there is no reservation, otherwise he would order reservation<n><n>## Solution<n><n># Program<n><n>```swift<n>class Solution {<n>    class func answerTheQuestion(_ input: Input) -> Output {<n>        switch input.question {<n>        case("How many days are in February?"):<n>            return 28 // Feb only has 28 days<n>        case("What are the first two odd numbers?"):<n>            return [1,3]<n>        case("How old is the elder man?", 3):<n>            return 30<n>        case("What time is the party at?", ["8PM", "9PM"]):<n>            return "8PM"<n>        case("What is the remainder after dividing 231 by 14?", 50):<n>            return 17 /// the remainder is 17<n>        case("What percent of a class of 18 students has a pet?", [5,4,14,9,11,17]):<n>            return "17%"<n>        case("When is April the 4th, but January the 32nd?", 13):<n>            return "Jan 32"<n>        default:<n>            print("Answer the question")<n>        }<n>    }<n>}<n><n>```<n>

His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh‚Äôs mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>### Input:Where can you buy a hairbrush along with bandages? Choices:  A: drugstore B: hospital C: bedroom D: car E: house<n><n>### Response:		Answer: Cars.<n><n>### Input/Response:What time is it? Choices:A: 4 pm B: 7 pm C: 8 pm D: 9 pm<n><n>### Response<n>Answer:C<n><n>### Input<n>Cindy has ten coins. Six coins are pennies and four coins are quarters. Each quarter is worth a hundred pennies. Write an expression to illustrate the total value of the coins that Cindy has.<n><n>### Response.<n><n>Answer:<n>  (1000/100)*10*6=600<n><n>###<n>### <n>### Input/ Response:Rosie and Hannah have 50 tulips. Rosie has two large tulips, two medium tulips, and two small tulips. Hannah has four medium tulips and three small tulips. If Rosie sells one large and one small tulip to Hannah, how many tulips does Rosie still have?<n><n>### Response :<n>Answer : (150)/10 = 50 Tulips<n><n>## <n>##<n>##<n>##<n><n><n>### Input :<n>Two birds, Jack and Jill, are on a branch. If Jack has a head start and spends 20 minutes on the branch, Jill can catch up and pass Jack in 60 minutes. How long does it take for Jack to get to the branch, all things considered?<n><n>### Answer:<n>Jack spends 60 minutes on the branch. So it takes him 60 minutes. <n><n>### Input 1:<n>A woman sells 15 cappuccinos each day for $6.00, 9 iced coffees for $1.25 apiece, and 4 drinks made with orange juice for $3.00 apiece. How much money does the woman earn during the week that has 5 weekdays and 6 weekend days?<n><n>### Input2 :<n>Each day that the store sells 14 cappuccinos and 3 iced coffees.<n><n>###Answer :<n>The woman earns $184 per day, and a total of $1068 during the five days

How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh‚Äôs mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh‚Äôs mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>### Input:Where you have finished a conversation with a person what do you say? Choices:  A: open letter B: thank god C: say goodbye D: bless you E: listen to radio<n><n>### Response:		A. Open letter<n><n>### Instructions.<n><n>1. Use the code snippet to create an application(app.js)<n>2. Define a variable (name= app and code) on line 4 of the code snippet to define that is an application <n>3. Create a variable (name= greetings) on line 6 of the code snippet. <n>4. Create an function (on line 7 of the code snippet) named hello(greetings) function with parameter(name=greetings) to define the object of that function. <n>5. Create variables (name = age,name = greetings2, name = greetings, name = greet, name = name, name = first, name = last<n>      on line 14 to 19 for data input)<n>6. Create an variable (name = name = input.name to get the data  from html.on line 20 of the code snippet.)<n>7. In the same line of the code snippet declare the function (name = changeName(name=input.name,age=input.age, first=input.first, last=input.last))<n>8. Create a function (name = greet (name=input.name)) on line 8 to print a String (line 10 of the code snippet) value.<n>9. Call a function (name=greeting(name=greet, name=age, name=first, name=last)) on line 8 of the code snippet.<n>10. Call a function(name=myGreeting(first=input.first))to display first on line 22 on the output window.

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh‚Äôs mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>### Input:Where would you put a computer other than a desk? How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. To do division, you find the "remainder," which is how many times the original number goes into the number you are dividing. For example, if I were given a number, and I divided it in half, then divided again, the remainder of the "third division" is how many times the number before me goes into it. His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. Choices:  A: city centre B: lottery ticket C: maps D: street E: busy city<n><n>### Response:		The answer is D<n><n>```python<n>import random<n><n># Create a random int between 1 and 10<n>n = random.randint(1, 10)<n><n># Create the choices as strings<n>choices = [<n>    "city centre",<n>    "lottery ticket",<n>    "maps",<n>    "busy city"<n>]<n>```<n><n>### Instructions:<n><n>While it is possible for a program to have randomness built into its architecture, that is not the only way it can be random. You can do things that are "according to chance" in several different ways.<n><n>This exercise will allow you to learn and then practice several of these ways for random number generation, in languages of your choosing.<n><n>First, let's start by defining what we are trying to do. We will create a random number of a fixed precision. That is, we will output an `Int`, `Int[10]` in this case (1-10), rather than simply allowing the `randint` function to choose one in a range of [0, `int.max()`].<n><n>A few notes before we get started.<n><n>- If you are creating this in Python, there is a decent example here: https://stackoverflow.com/a/55999422/5123108<n>- If you are doing this in Javascript, you can see one solution here: https://stackoverflow<n><n>With that out of the way, let's see how this works for multiple languages. I highly recommend you try at least two languages to keep things more interesting.<n><n>(1) Python, (2) Javascript, (3) Actionscript, (4) Bash shell, (5) Ruby, (6) Visual Studio, etc.<n><n>### Solution:<n><n>Create a code snippet for at least 2 languages. Each snippet should do the following:<n><n>- Create a `int[]`<n>- Set the precision to `10` (1 - 10)<n>- Create a random number between 0 and the precision value<n>- Set the number to a string<n>- Test if your number is divisible by 3.<n><n>### Sample answers:<n><n>#### Python<n><n>```<n>>>> precision = 10<n>>>> x = randrange(0, precision)<n>>>> if x

To each one you will add a second sentence.  Both sentences will contain the word ‚Äòbecause‚Äô.  For each sentence you may choose different kinds of reasons. Reasons may be in the subject of the additional sentence, may be mentioned in the additional sentence, or may appear in the additional sentence by word order, such as because of, due to, caused by, etc.  You may choose different kinds of sentences as subjects.  The final sentence is to be about your friend‚Äôs shoelaces because they are loose and they are in the way.<n><n>**Sentences:**<n><n>(a) My shoelaces are loose and they are getting in the way.<n>(b) My shoelaces‚Äô colors are different from one another. (c) My right shoelace is shorter than my left shoelace.<n>(d) My shoelaces feel like they are too loose.<n>(e) I want my shoes to look as good as new.<n>(f) I should tie the laces very tight and make sure they do not fall again.<n>(g) I have lost a lot of laces because of broken strings.<n>(h) My shoelaces look strange.<n><n>### Exercise:<n><n>### Sentence 1:<n><n>### Explanation:**A, B, or C**<n><n>### Sentences 2:<n><n>### A, B, or C:<n><n>### Instactions<n><n>### Instctions:<n>In each pair of input and output statements, draw a line between the two statements. only 3 passengers and 1 seat, the next passenger will need to wait for 2 minutes to be able to take the seat

If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>### Input:Sally took her medicine and experienced strong side effects.  What did doctors say about the side effects? Choices:  A: great B: distinguished C: remarkable D: excellent E: peculiar<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>B) Great<n><n>When the side effects of a medicine are distinct or remarkable, it is used to describe the side effect itself. It is like saying the medicine was extraordinary in some form and there isn‚Äôt much to compare it to.<n><n>For example, if someone were to refer to a drug and say ‚Äúit really has great side effects‚Äù there is no comparison of the drug to anything else.<n><n>While if someone says ‚Äúit has side effects that are great in comparison to the other drugs I‚Äôve tried‚Äù they‚Äôre explaining the side effects in relation to the other drugs that were tried and the side effects of those drugs in comparison to the drug being tried (the drug with the side effects that are great).<n><n>Answer choices:<n><n>The side effects are distinguished means that there are many things that are similar and there are many things unique/different from the rest.<n><n>The side effects of the medicine are extremely high. You might find other drugs, but you don't find many drugs with similar side effects.<n><n>The side effect is remarkable. This term is used when something is different from many other things; it stands out.<n><n><n>The side effects could be defined as excellent. Excellent is another way to say extraordinary. With that said, when a person says "The medicine is excellent," they are saying that it is unusual, noteworthy, and extraordinary.<n><n>Answer choices:E) Peculiar<n><n>There are a few meanings to this term. A peculiar definition is unusual; this is to say that strange or unexpected.<n><n>### Input : <n>Margaret is going to run laps with three to four laps being the same path around the stadium as a mile.  Her uncle says three laps is a mile, but her aunt says her uncle isn't right. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh‚Äôs mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>### Input:You can buy a pen here. Choices:  A: briefcase B: pocket C: friend's house D: office supply store E: classroom<n><n>### Response:		I would like to buy a pen.<n><n>### Input :Please ask for a large coffee when you order.<n><n>### Response :Ok. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>### Input:The crowd wasn't that big. Choices:  A: field B: alone C: small group D: solitude E: solitary<n><n>### Response:		<n>- Field<n><n>### Input2:The number of people in the restaurant was too high and they had to go to an overcrowded movie.  There were so many actors and singers in the performance that it was hard to figure out who was who.  Did the actors and singers do a tremendous job of performing that it left the audience stunned or did these acts fall flat?  Choices: A: A tremendous B: a tremendous C: stunningly D: stunning E: stupendous<n><n>### Response2:<n>- Stunning<n><n>{% highlight ruby linenos %}<n>def show_task(t)<n> puts "The task is #{t}"<n>end <n><n>def show_data(d)<n> puts d<n>end<n><n>def show_answer(a)<n> puts "The solution is #{a}"<n>end<n>{% endhighlight %}<n><n>### Solution:<n>def show_task(&block)<n> puts "The instructions are as follows"<n> block.call<n>end<n><n>def solution_data<n>    [<n>        {<n>            name: 'Karen'<n>            age: 84<n>            favorite_color: 'Blue'<n>        },<n>        {<n>            age: 97<n>            name: 'Fred'<n>            favorite_color:'Pink'<n>        }<n>    ]<n>end<n><n>def call_show_data<n>    show_data(solution_data)<n>end<n><n>def validate_task(t)  <n>    if t == "Which data comes first?"<n>        puts "Answer is data with less items"<n>        return<n>    elsif t == "Which item is first in data?"<n>        puts "The first item in the array is Karen"<n>        return<n>        end<n>else<n>    puts "Wrong, please retry"<n>end<n><n>def calc_task(task)<n>    if task == "Karen is 2 years older than Fred"<n>    puts "'Karen is 2 older than Fred'. Check."<n>    end<n>end<n><n>def task_list<n>    task_list<n>end<n><n>def answer_task<n>    puts "The result is data with 1 items"<n>end<n><n>if __FILE__ == $0<n>    t_string = ARGV[0]<n>    t_string.to_

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh‚Äôs mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>### Input:If clothes have developed a smell and can't be washed what should you do with them? Choices:  A: hang in closet B: sniff C: get dirty D: become soiled E: air out<n><n>### Response:		<n>Answer: Option B: Air out<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following multiple-choice question.<n><n>## Instructions: Answer the following multiple-choice Question (1 point)<n>## Instructions<n>### Instruction: Answer the following multiple choice question, based on the clues provided. Write a response that adequately completes the request.\n\n### Demonstrations\n### Instruction: Answer the following multiple - choice question, based on what is provided and show all\n### work. Write a response that accurately answers the question.\n\nInput: Josh‚Äôs grandma gave him one toy every day for the month of June. He got one stuffed animal on the\n\n21st and three more toys that month. If he got 28 toys from his grandma in the month of June,\n\nhow many more days were there in June than July? (4 points)<n>### Response: (2 points)\n\nIn the month of June, Josh received one toy per day.   Therefore, there were 30-days in June.\n\nJuly only had 28 days per month.  Since July only had 28-days and Josh only got 28\n\ntoys, we know that June had at least 1 \n\nmore day than July.<n><n>### The correct answer to this question is the following (0 points)\n\nJuly is exactly a month before June.  So, June must've had 31-days and July\n\nonly had 30-days.  Therefore, June had at least one more day than July and at least\n\n31-days.<n>

How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. And they're an excellent source of vitamins, minerals, and antioxidants. And they're also one of the healthiest foods you can eat. <n><n>B) The answer is _B_, because they contain lots of antioxidants, vitamins, and other nutrients that are good for your health. <n><n>C) The answer is _C_, because they're very tasty when eaten out of hand. They're also excellent when made into salad dressings.<n><n>D) The answer is _D_, because they contain lots iron, copper, zinc, calcium, magnesium, potassium, riboflavin and phosphorus-all vitamins that your body needs for energy production. Also, olives are high in polyphenolswhich are plant-based compounds that are believed to help fight disease by reducing inflammation and boosting the immune system. <n><n>E) The answer is _E_, because refrigerators keep olives cool so they don't spoil as quickly.<n><n>### Input : A: How long did it take Sara to finish her math homework? If she draws 2 marbles without replacing them, what is the probability of getting at least 1 yellow marble?<n><n>### Response<n><n>One possibility that occurred is "outside", which means a possibility of getting at least one yellow marble.<n><n>If the probability of selecting a yellow marble when a yellow marble is drawn is 3 out of 8, or 0.375.<n><n>In order to calculate:<n>* The probability of selecting one yellow marble when one yellow marble is selected which is 0.370<n>* The probability of getting no yellow marbles when selected is 2.777.<n><n>### Input.<n><n>Alexander had a total of 1600 jellybeans. How many jellybeans did Alexander left?<n><n>### Answer<n><n>Total number of jellybeans = 1600<n><n>Jellybean of each divided jars = 1/3<n><n>Therefore, Jellybean of 0.8(700) and 0.1 (500)<n><n>Alexander ate 0.13(50) jellybeans<n><n>Therefore, 1697 jellybeans remained<n><n>### Inputs<n><n>In the carnival, there is a dart game, where two darts are thrown together, and if they both hit bull's eye, the player will win an award for free. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>### Input:If I am forgiving, what hidden force may be activated in my life? Choices:  A: nice feeling B: good karma C: respect D: new freedom E: good heart<n><n>### Response:		I choose B.<n><n>My first choice because I always help to every person and any problem. But sometimes, I don't ask for forgiveness if I make mistakes.<n><n>Answer: I choose D.<n><n>My second choice because this will make me feel good and happy. If I say sorry for a mistake that I did, it will make me feel better.<n>
