Choices:  A: ignore B: enforce C: authoritarian D: yell at E: avoid<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>Incorrect<n><n>The sanctions against the student were a punishing blow and they seemed to undermine the efforts the school had been making to make a positive change.<n><n>Correct<n>The sanctions against what the student had been making to make change seemed to undermine a punishing blow.<n><n>Incorrect<n>The sanctions against The student were a punishing what seemed to the efforts the school had making been to change.<n><n>Corrrect<n>The sanctions what against The student seemed to the efforts the  school had been making to change which was a punishing blow. "were" and "seemed" are passives. The passive is used for the focus to be on what is done or happened, usually in the past.<n><n>Incorrect <n>The sanctions against school were a punishing for the student they had seemed to make efforts what The.<n><n>Correction:<n><n>The sanctions were a punishing blow against the school which seemed to what the efforts The student had made to make change.<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh‚Äôs mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>### Input:The fox walked from the city into the forest, what was it looking for? Choices:  A: pretty flowers. B: hen house C: natural habitat D: storybook E: dense forest<n><n>### Response:		<n>If it was the fox we would say it was looking for one or the other, but if it is a baby fox we would say the fox was looking for the mother.<n><n>### Input<n>A student ate 1/3 of a large pizza and drank 2/5 cups of soda. How much more soda needs the student to drink to match the number of the slice of pizza eaten?<n>Answer: 5/3<n><n>### Input1:The fox is looking for a hen house. What did it find? Choices: It found A: a storybook B: a house C: natural habitat E: a dense forest D: pretty flowers<n><n>### Response<n>It can't find anything it is still looking in the forest.<n><n>### input<n>Jack ate 3/5 of the cupcake and John ate 7/10 of the cupcake.  How many cups of cupcake does Jack eat if Jack eats 2 more cupcakes than John?<n><n>### Input2:<n>The fox is looking in a storybook, what did the fox find? Choices: A: a natural habitat B: a home C: 2 cups of cupcakes D: 2/3 of the cupcakes E: 4/5 of the cupcakes<n><n>### response<n>It didn't find anything in the storybook<n><n>### Input3:<n>A student got 40% of the final grade in math and 210% of the final marks in history. If the student's final math marks were 80% and final history marks were 30% of the total grade in each subject, what was the total percentage of their final grade mark in all subjects?<n><n>### response1:<n>320%<n><n>### Input4:<n>When Daisy was on vacation she spent two thirds of her budget. After spending every last penny in her budget, she realized it was only one third of her allotted budget. How much money was in her budget at the beginning of her trip?<n><n>### Response2:<n>If you were to spend 2/3 of a sandwich and one more slice, it is one more slice than 2/3 of it.<n><n>### Example Input5

Shirt pocket<n><n>### Input<n>> I wonder how much money he will have after paying his debts.<n><n>### Response<n>> About 200 dollars.<n>  <n>### Solution: Write a program that given the description, returns the answer to the question or the user friendly response to the person.<n><n>Solutions may have multiple steps.<n><n>### Input Example:<n><n>### Response Example:<n><n>## Part 2: Review of Program Design- This section will be covered in later videos<n><n>### Input for Part 1:Answer the following multiple-choice question:<n><n>In this part you will be implementing a program that will demonstrate a design pattern for the program. The first line of the input contains a integer n (1 < n < 100).  The second line contains n integers in parentheses.  These integers are used to make up the inputs to your program.  The input will be in the format of:<n><n>(N(X).Y1)(N(X).Y2)(N(X).Z)<n><n>There will be a space between a parentheses and the first integer, then a space between a parenthesis and the dot.  The dot is followed by a space which is followed by a letter followed by a space.  The letter in parenthesis is the name of the individual and the letters after the dot represent the year in which this individual was born.<n><n>Each of the integers in the input will be used to determine which day the individual passed away in.  The first input will determine in which year the individual passed away.  The second integer will be the month when this individual passed away.  This month will be chosen based on 12 different values: 1-12.  The third integer will be the day in the year in which the individual passed away.<n><n>There may be multiple cases within the array in which no individuals passed away on a particular day, or only one.<n><n>Your output should tell the user the name of the individual who passed away in that day. After you've printed the name of the individual, print "The day of the week when they passed away was: Wednesday or Thursday" followed by a blank line.<n><n>### Solution:<n>This program is a complete solution to the input shown above.<n>

Choices:  A: knife wounds B: buy a gun C: bleeding D: jail time E: law suit<n><n>### Response:		<n>Input: Joe suffered many consequences from stabing a stranger to death... the family of the victim went to court against him.<n><n>### Input<n>Tina wants to visit the park. There is a ticket machine next to the entrance gate. How much coin can she put to get a discount and be able to purchase a ticket?  Tickets cost $1.25 and she has 5 1-dollar bills.<n><n>### Response<n>Tina wants to buy a ticket to enter the park, so she goes to the ticket machine to buy her ticket, but there are no 1-Dollar bills on the machine, she then has 5 50-cent pieces coins, to be able to get the ticket with a discount she has to go to another machine with a larger amount, at this machine she has enough money to buy the ticket + discount but not enough of the ticket, since she has a 50-cent piece short, her only option is the use a quarter over the ticket, so Tina should look for the second machine which has the larger coins and that will be able to provide her the ticket + discount.<n><n>### Output<n><n>### Input :   Three years ago, the Earth was visited by an alien spaceship.  Two and half years ago, there was a volcano eruption on the Sun and one year ago, there was a famine in the Moon.  How many years ago is this happening?<n><n>### Response : <n>4

If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh‚Äôs mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>### Input:Where in Southern Europe would you find many canals? Choices:  A: near B: closeness C: here D: proximity E: this<n><n>### Response:		D is correct.<n><n>### Justification<n>A: "Near" (adj.) means close to something, but not quite touching or against. A sensor is used to determine the distance, not the closeness, of an object from another object.<n>B: In this context, "closeness" means nearness or the proximity of an object. A sensor is not used to determine closeness or nearness, but distance instead.<n>C: The term "here" refers to place or position. A sensor used to detect distance would not have anything to do with position.<n>D: "Proximity" refers to both being near an object and its spatial closeness to something else. A sensor is not a sensor used to determine proximity (spatial closeness).<n>E: "This" is an inappropriate term to use since it would mean the sensor. The correct choice is D, as it is clearly the only one that makes sense in relation to the given example.<n><n>### What is the most significant piece of advice for new coders?<n><n>### What do you think will be significant about HTML5?<n><n>### How would you change the color on a radio button if it already had a background-color property of aquamarine?<n><n>### Please review and provide 2 pieces of constructive criticism.<n>

How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. What would he have told her before she entered the seventh grade or the ninth grade? When she was seven years old?When she was<n><n>### Response<n><n>#### Advice from a father<n>I have been a manager of many employees, it is extremely difficult to give useful advice to employees as a manager. The reason is that there is a vast difference in competencies between managers and juniors, and juniors may feel insecure or may be intimidated by managers. My advice would be first to let the juniors know the work style of me and the company. Then, I would give useful advice based on the differences in work ethics between juniors and myself. For example, when some juniors become disorganized, I would tell them "we should work the way that a secretary in my company does." For example, when I work with a manager from another organization, I do not do what I cannot do such as using my secretary's telephone number but using mine or sending an e-mail without thinking about my message. That is a work style that is necessary for working with a colleague. In the workplace environment, I do not tell everyone that I follow this rule, but I tell colleagues who are not my juniors, such as managers from other departments and managers from businesses. My colleagues are likely to tell the juniors who are not my colleagues about this, and it will lead to the success in the relationship between me and the juniors. Thus, it is necessary to make the other person know the standards of your work before you give someones advice. An example is to share my rule with colleagues about using my secretary's phone number before handing over the tip to juniors.<n><n>#### Advice between siblings<n>I would give to a person who comes from a rich and powerful family the same advice as that for a boss from the other company. Basically, I would give useful and timely advice by considering the person's work style. For example, I would give helpful advice on work skills. I believe that these pieces of advice will influence the person'

Choices:  A: music room B: music store C: music class D: medium E: house<n><n>### Response:		<n>```Python<n>from typing import Dict<n><n><n>def find_answer(question: str) -> Dict[str, int]:<n><n>    answer = dict()<n><n>    if question == "A: music room":<n>        answer['music room'] = 1<n><n>    elif question == "B: music store":<n>        answer['store'] = 2<n><n>    elif question[0] == "C: music class":<n>        answer['school'] = 3<n><n>    elif question in ["D: medium", "E: house"]:<n>        answer['home'] = 4<n><n>    elif question.startswith("Where would someone learn to"):<n>        answer['music'] = 5<n><n>    return answer<n>```<n><n>### Demostration:<n>```Python<n>input = """Where would someone learn to<n>play an upright piano?"""<n>```<n><n>```Python<n>answer = find_answer(input)<n>```<n><n>*Output: *Answer: "music room"<n><n>*Output: 1<n>

How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh‚Äôs mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. Be sure to include any whitespace that you would enter on the command line.<n>### Your program should print the parameter with no line breaks in-between any of the characters of the parameter. But if there‚Äôs a line break in-between any characters in the parameter the line break should count as part of the parameter instead of it being displayed as one end of the parameter followed by one end of the line break, then another end of the parameter. For example, if the parameter is ‚ÄúHello World‚Äù then your program should print out ‚ÄúHello World‚Äù not just a blank line followed by ‚ÄúHello World‚Äù. Avoid line breaks that you can place in your code and print in your function. Instead, create and use a specific line break (such as CR or LF) to place it at the end.<n><n>### Task:<n><n>Write a program that prints the same output as the one below.<n>To complete this task you should use the two prompts below.<n>To print out the value of a, call thisPrompt( ‚ÄúThis is a test‚Äù );<n>To print out the word ‚Äútest‚Äù, and then a blank line, call printThisWord( ‚ÄúThis is another test‚Äù );<n><n>### Output<n><n>This is test This is a test<n>This is another test<n><n>### Program:<n><n>The code below does not run with an error. She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh‚Äôs mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>### Input:What are you hoping to achieve when talking to someone? Choices:  A: communicating with others B: hurt feelings C: dry mouth D: intimacy E: changing behavior<n><n>### Response:		 Dry mouth, communicating with others, to hurt feelings, to changing behavior<n><n>##: <n>

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh‚Äôs mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>### Input:If your watching television and accomplish nothing what have you done? Choices:  A: getting fat B: get fat C: typing words D: falling asleep E: wasted time<n><n>### Response:		Your answer is C: typing words<n><n>### Input If your eating dinner and accomplish nothing what have done? Choices: A: grow fat B: get fat and get fat C: type words D: sleep E: doing nothing<n><n>### Response your answer is C: type words<n><n>### If you are typing and accomplish nothing what have have done? Choices are: A: get fat B: get fat D: sleep E: grow fat<n><n>### Response is D: grow fat<n><n>```<n>Example:<n><n>Input: If your eating dinner in the morning but you dont know what to eat and you just eat something what would you eat? Choices are : A: potato B: sandwich C: apple D: chips E: rice<n><n>What do you want to eat for dinner?<n><n>  Choices are: A; D : rice<n>```<n><n><n>```<n>Example response:<n><n>D, rice<n>```<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh‚Äôs mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>### Input:In the middle of the day what will someone do because of being hungry? Choices:  A: cook dinner B: make bread C: eat in restaurant D: have lunch E: make bread<n><n>### Response:		<n>A:E<n><n>### Description:<n>The task will require the output to be either lowercase or capital letter. I am using uppercase letters to show the answer I want and lowercase letters for the choices.<n><n>### Input<n>  Input:John did not have any money to buy candy. He asked Peter for money, and Peter asked Jack for money, and Jack asked John for money, and so on around the town. All the boys had less money with each person asking than before they asked. The last boy had $0.11. How much did John start out with?<n><n>### Output<n>John had $0<n><n>### Explanation<n>[John did not have any left]<n>(and with each person asking) [with each person asking]<n>[each person asked] [they had] [with each asking]<n>the last boy [how] [at the end] (had [he] the last boy [he] had [he] $0.11 [he] had $0.1)<n><n>### Input Choice<n>A:John had $0.25<n>B: John had $1.25<n>C: John had $2.75<n>D: John had no money left<n>E: John had $3.75<n><n>### Input Description<n>Description:The task will require the input to be between 0 and 10 dollars. I will show 0 and 11 as answers to the choices.<n><n><n><n>###### ¬©2019-2021<n>###### by [Muhammad Anwes Alam](https://github.com/MAAnwes)
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh‚Äôs mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>### Input:Where can peanut butter be stored? Choices:  A: container B: supermarket C: pantry D: sandwich E: jar<n><n>### Response:		A: container<n><n>### Input-Output:<n>Input:Jason was playing in the yard.<n>Output: Jason went into the garage to get a ball.<n><n>### Response-Input:Answer the following multiple-choice question.<n><n>## Output-Question:Answer the following multiple - choice question.<n><n><n>### Instructions:<n>Input: Sarah wants to make a gift for her friend for her birthday. She wanted to sew an apron and a stuffed animal and she need 22 inches of fabric to make an apron and 53 inches of fabric to make the stuffed animal. 104 inches of fabric will fit in a box 12 inches high and 16 inches wide.  If she needs 120 inches of fabric to wrap up the boxes, how many boxes of fabric does Sandra need to buy to complete her gift?<n>Answer: 7<n><n>Input: Sarah wants make a gift for her nephew. The stuffed animal she bought was in the back of his closet, which held 46 boxes of stuffed animals; 29 of which were the same size and 17 of which were different.  Two more boxes of animals need to be added to fill out the closet before Sarah can buy something else. If there are 56 empty boxes (total number of boxes held or can hold a stuffed animal) in the closet, what is the total number (size) of the stuffed animals in the closet?<n>Answer: 51<n><n>Input: A group of school friends was planning to buy pencils for their teachers. They found a discount store which sold pencils of eight different types in various assortments. Some of the pencils were number 2 pencils, some were black, some were red, some were blue, and so on. Of a set of different types of pencils and assortments, what was the total number of available pencils?<n>Answer: 88<n><n>Input: If Sarah has an apple, an artichoke, and a beet and there are 9 apples in a pound of apples, 12 artichokes in a pound of artichokes, and 6 beets in a pound of beets, what is the total weight of the fruit that she has?<n>Answer: 9 lbs

Choices:  A: wedding B: friend's house C: internet cafe D: movie E: restaurant<n><n>### Response:		<n>```<n><n>	[Choose an option]<n>		1.<n>		1.A<n>		2.<n>		2.B<n>		3.<n>		3.C<n>		4.<n>		4.D<n>		5.<n>		5.E<n>```<n><n>### Instructions:<n>1. You get to play the role of [the interviewer].<n>2. The response needs to use at least 4 different questions.<n><n>### Example Input:<n>Input: Hi.  My name is [name].  I'm looking for a job as a writer at [company].<n><n>### Example Response:<n>Hi, [name].  Thanks for applying for the job!  Do you have any writing experience?  Are you currently in school?  What is your dream job?  Why do you want to be a writer?<n><n>### Note:  Make sure to write different questions and that the questions build off of each other by asking clarifying questions or using synonyms (e.g. instead of asking "why do you like reading so much?").<n>

Choices:  A: michigan B: wyoming C: mississippi D: tennessee E: mississippi<n><n>### Response:		<n>If you take a look at the question, you would notice that the choices have to do with the city. This means that it should be about the name of the city, while the choices should be a list of cities related with the Jackson in the United States.<n><n>In other words, if you look at the letters of "Jackson", you would see that its states are: "MI", "MA", "MS", and "TN". We can use these 4 letters to make 4 different choices:<n><n>MICHIGAN --> MI<n>MISSISSIPPI --> MS<n>MASSACHUSETTS --> MA<n>TENNISSEE --> TN.<n><n>Since we've already answered the question correctly, there's nothing to change or fix.<n>

He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. Choices:  A: violin case B: symphony orchestra C: class D: learning to play violin E: music store<n><n>### Response:		John made first violin in the symphony orchestra.<n><n>### Input<n><n>Input:What is 999 x 100?<n>Answer: 99,000 Choices: A: 999,002 B: 1,990 C: 998,102<n><n>### Output<n><n>Output:B.<n>1) 999 * 1 is your answer and 100 x 999 is your answer as well.  You cannot get another 0 at the end.<n>2) 998*1 = 998 therefore you have to subtract 1 from 999.<n><n>### Output: <n>B.<n>1) You cannot have two zeros in a row.<n>2) You subtracted 100 from 1000 and got 999<n>### Input:<n>Input: The train departs from 1100 AM until 0130 PM.<n>Answer: 2830<n><n>### Output <n>Based on the above answer<n>You have to take 1300 hours<n><n>### Input <n>Input:I have an equation where b=212+5c-9d-3e-10f. What is c?<n><n>### Output :<n>B. The sum of the given series is the series that the equation represents.<n><n>### Explanation of input<n><n>B means: C is the middle term.<n><n>### Increasing sequence:<n>Increasing means the number in a series gets greater as you go farther along, e.g. 3, 7, 9, 10, 11.<n><n>Decreasing: 9, 6, 3, 2, 1.<n><n>### Decreasing:<n>Decreasing means the number in the series gets smaller as you go farther along. This means the opposite of increasing. In a decreasing sequence the series goes from a greater value to a lesser value.<n><n>### A and B are the opposite of each other:<n>a<b;b>a<n><n>### Input :<n><n>Input: 0.07 0.57 0.95 0.91 1.05

The third step is to practice playing the guitar every day.<n>Output:<n>Answer:<n><n>### Demo 2:<n>Input:Inorder to play the trumpet, the first step is learning how to hold the trumpet. Choices:  A: satisfaction B: flying C: sweating D: falling down E: trip<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>Sweating is one of many things that runners will endure in their sport.  The question does not specify what sort of run. For example, a track runner or a cross-country runner (or any other type of long distance runner) will perspire in humid environments whereas someone that plays a tennis match in a gymnasium will sweat similarly for different reasons.  The correct response should focus on how sweating is a common experience for people that runs for various distances.  <n><n>One can argue that runners feel other kinds of 'flights' and 'falls' as they exert themselves.  However, this is a question of perspective.  Flights can only refer to a bird or other flying creature that is used as a metaphor to denote a soaring and graceful activity, whereas 'falls' can also relate to an unfortunate incident or disaster.  <n><n>Finally, trips can refer to a slip, stumble or a different kind of error.  <n><n>### Instructions:Complete the task<n><n>### Instruct:Sophia's favorite fruits are strawberries and kiwis. Sophia wanted to try the rest of the strawberries instead.  She ate half and decided to get some more, which left her with 234 strawberries.  If the strawberries at the store cost $50 for the entire bunch, what is the price of one strawberry? Solve for x.)<n><n>### Instuct:A friend challenged Sally that if she can lift five pounds on her left leg twice as many times as she can on her right leg using arm weights she is smarter. Choices:  A: do crossword puzzle B: see art C: give up D: grocery shop E: play chess<n><n>### Response:		A. <n><n>### Instructions: Write a response to the question below.<n><n>### Problem: Dotty's favorite food is chocolate cake and chocolate chip cookie. She can eat 18 chocolate cakes and 160 chocolate chip cookies each day. Each week, she saves so much money, she can have  a soda each day, a fancy lunch once a week, and dessert when ever ever she likes. Her lunches are $5 each, desserts are $7 each and the soda is $2.50. What is the maximum amount of money, in dollars, she can save each week?<n><n>### Solution:<n><n>### Solution-Response:<n>First, lets answer each food and see what we can say.<n>Chocolate Cake: The question states each week Dotty saves $367.50, therefore if she can afford 18 cakes we get 18 * $367.25 = $6764 (6764 cents/2 dollars =3382)<n><n>Chocolate Chip Cookies: The question states each 7 days she can afford 160 cookies, therefore 160 * $35 = $560 (560 dollars/2 - $1498)<n><n>If we add the savings of the chocolate cake which is 6764+560 we get 7324. The question says that Dotty can have a daily soda of 5 dollars. It is easier to count down the amount of money that Dotty is left with after the soda therefore we subtract 5 each day the amount left will be 7324 -5 (7324-5=7320)<n><n>A fancy lunch means that each week she can have one for 5 dollars. Therefore we add 5 each week the amount left will be (7320+5*(1-1)) =7324<n><n>Deserts are 7 dollars each, we add 7 each week it will be 7371 (7371+7*(1-1))<n><n>We finally get down to the money left with which is 7366+13
Below is an instruction that describes a task. His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh‚Äôs mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. Choices:  A: necklace B: wall outlet fixture C: tool box D: computer E: motorcycle<n><n>### Response:		<n>The chain ring is attached to the bicycle chain that is used to power a bicycle.<n><n>### Input:: My kids need to read at least 20 chapters of their assigned novel by the end of the school year. Each of them can make it up to 5 days after the end of the year. How much time does each of them need to read each day to finish the assignment?<n><n>### Response::  5 days / 20 chapters / chapters per day * 20 / 3 = 5 books per day<n><n>### Input; A cowboy riding a horse travels 480 miles in 18 days. How many miles does he travel each day?<n><n><n>### Response; 480/18 = 27, so the cowboy travels 27 miles per day<n><n>## Description<n><n>The solution is to write a recursive function to calculate how much time each of the 6 friends will<n>need by themselves in order to finish their work. If all the friends are able to work together<n>on their assignment with one time each, then it would only take 60 minutes. However, due to<n>their schedules which vary from week to week, one friend is busy each week and cannot work on<n>the assignment.<n><n>The amount of time each person needs to complete their assignment depends on the amount of<n>time each other person finished their assignment for that day. For example, if one person<n>needs another 30 hours to finish their assignment, so they work on it for 10 hours on Friday,<n>the other five people need another 3x25=75 minutes to finish their assignment. These 75<n>minutes can be divided equally amongst the 5 remaining people so all people finish at 15<n>minutes apart.<n><n>The problem can be approached recursively, i.e. if we have answered time needed for one<n>person then we need to know the time needed for the remaining people, and as we saw above<n>this depends on how much time the other people finished. We can calculate all the times<n>necessary for the remaining people recursively.<n><n>Since the problem is recursive we must have a helper method that returns the previous<n>calculation (i.e. what time is needed by the helper). If we had a helper that returned the<n>time we first calculate we

The magazines are kept at home.<n><n>### InputWhere is the tallest mountain? Choices:  a: South America b: Europe c: Asia d: North America e: Africa<n><n>### ResponseBecause the correct mountain the chosen is North America the correct complete sentence is e. There are many mountains in Africa, Asia and Europe but the tallest is located in North America.<n><n>### Recommendation<n><n>When you see that you are in doubt about the choices given you can always consult a dictionary or a thesaurus that will give you other synonyms or terms that mean the same things.

Choices:  A: blisters B: frustration C: being paid D: make money E: money<n><n>### Response:		C is correct<n><n>### Instructions:How many minutes are there in a week? How many hours are there in a year? How many years are there in a decade? How many decades are there in a century? In these questions, we are looking at the difference in amount in the two cases by just subtracting the two amounts. In the first question, for instance, we found out that a week has 1/7 of a year, or 42 minutes. Similarly, we can look at the question about decade and year to reach the answer that a decade has 10 years or a century has 10 decades.<n><n>### Explanation:Since a day are 24 hours, a month is 30 days, we can say that a month has 30 minutes and three months is 90 minutes. Using this and the example on minutes in a week, we can say that 3 months is also 90 minutes. Also, if a year has 365 days, a decade also has 3650 days or 10 years.

Write a response that gives several methods.<n>### Input<n>The difference between a number'smess than 100 hundred, tens, and ones position? Choices: A: subtract 100 B: subtract 10 times its ones position C: subtract its ones position and divide by 10 D: divide its ones position by 10 E: add 100 more to 1 plus its ones position<n><n>### Response<n> A:add 100 more<n>1)the ones positionis the digit in the ones spot.  (1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9)<n>2) the tens position is the number that is in the tens spot<n>(1 to 6 to 13, 14, 15)<n>3) the hundreds position is 1, 2, or 3 times the tens position.<n>(10 to 100 to 200)<n><n>4) the difference is to take the product and take away 99<n>Example 1:  10-99 = -89<n>Example 2:  21-99 =  30<n>Example 3:  32-99 =  47<n>Example 4:  43-99 =  -56<n>Example 5:  54-99 =  65<n>Example 6:  65-99 =  24<n>Example 7:  67-99 =    -32<n>Hope this helps<n>

His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh‚Äôs mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>### Input:Billy bounced the ball off the wall.  There was a target on the wall for him to bounce against.  Where might he be? Choices:  A: pool table B: toy box C: playroom D: park E: closet<n><n>### Response:		Selecting the option to place the ball on the wall.<n><n>### Input Choice: A: pool table<n><n>### Response<n><n>### InputChoice:B: toy box<n><n>###Response:<n><n>### Input choice: C: Playroom<n><n>###Response<n><n>### Inputchoice: D: Park<n><n>### Response

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh‚Äôs mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>### Input:what do you do before going to party? Choices:  A: call 911 B: enjoy yourself C: get drunk D: having sex E: meet new people<n><n>### Response:		A or E if you are going to a party and you are a girl or E if you are a boy<n><n>### Input : Is it a girl or a boy: Choices: 0 for girl 1 for boy.<n>    <n>### Response:<n>0 if it is a boy and 1 if it is a girl<n>

He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn. If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh‚Äôs mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>### Input:The delivery man was delivering a whole crate of shampoo, they went through a lot of it at the what? Choices:  A: supermarket B: motel C: at hotel D: shampoo bottle E: hair salon<n><n>### Response:		<n>#### A<n><n>This is a multiple task and this is a simple math task. In this we can get all the information as in we can get the words they used in this case they use the words "a lot" which means we can take them to more than 10 but less then 20 means it is 12 shampoo bottles.<n><n>#### B<n><n>As per my response in this case if we want to do the task without any use of mathematical operation then it is a little tricky and we do it by memorizing the things.<n><n>#### Question:<n>#### A<n>```<n>Ans: 22.5 grams<n>```<n>#### B<n>```<n>Ans. 11.5 grams<n>Better Way to calculate <n>```<n><n>```<n>(0.6 * 24) + <n>((-0.6 * 1) + ((0.6 * 5)) / 25 + (0.6 * 3) / 4 ) + <n>((-1) / 15 + (2) / 45*13 + (3) / 45 )<n>```<n><n>###Input: A fruit vendor is selling mango which costs $1.00 each.  If a customer buys 25 mango, 36 mango, or 39 mango, what is the most change they get back?<n>Answer: 0.59<n>####Question:<n>####A<n>```<n>Ans 3543 dollars<n>```<n><n>####B<n>```<n>Ans<n>512.5 dollars<n>```<n><n>## Task 1<n>Write a program that can print odd numbers and multiples of those odd numbers. For example:<n><n>Input: 1<n><n>Output: <n>```<n>multiples of 1: 1,2,3,4,5,6<n>odd numbers: 1,3,5,7,9,11<n>```<n>Input: 4<n><n>Output:  ```<n>multiples of 4: 4,8,12,16<n>odd numbers:  4, 6, 8, 10, 12, 14, 16<n>```<n>Input: "3,9"<n><n>Output: ```<n>multiples of: 3,9

She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh‚Äôs mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>### Input:James didn't know what to do.  He felt that he'd ruin his relationship with Jen if he took it further, and he didn't want to do that.  At the same time,  He fight that pushing farther might do what to something good? Choices:  A: found B: destroy C: construct D: fix E: produce<n><n>### Response:		Choice: D<n><n>### Input and Response:<n>The student is responsible for coming up with the solution to this multiple choice problem. Choices:  A: music store B: orchestra C: jazz band D: rock band E: music studio<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>Answer: E: Music Studio<n><n>### Explanation:<n>Orchestra A<n>Clarinetist are always part of an orchestra.<n>Jazz band B<n>Clarinet players may be part of jazz band C<n>Rock band D<n>Clarinetist most likely will NEVER be part of a rock band ever<n>Music Store E<n>Only a Music store might be hiring clarinet players.<n>

The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. Some information, such as your email messages, may be stored so that you can access the information from home, the school, work, even another country.|<n>| 2 |Instead of storing data on your own computer's hard drive (or on a removable drive) or on a network drive that you can access in your office, at school, or at home; you can store information on the Webserver's drive. That is often called "cloud" storage.|<n><n>## 2.<n>|   |What are the two forms of cloud computing?   |    |Explain the two forms of cloud-computing.   <n>|---|:----:|----|:----:|<n>|   |

A command is always either one or two words (**NOT** three). One-word commands can be either a keyword or a function name (which will always be followed by an equal sign and a single expression). Two-word commands must consist of the keyword and an operand.<n><n>**The string must follow the correct format (with the correct number of spaces for commands).**<n><n>Input<n><n>```<n>Money is fun to spend<n>   1237<n>```<n><n>Answer<n><n>```python<n>'Money is fun to 1237 spend'<n>```<n><n>**Instrucitons: You can't just print the input and the answer; you must **<n>include all of the correct spacing between commands.<n><n>Input<n><n>   1<n>   2<n>   +<n>   =<n><n>Answer<n><n>   2<n>-6<n>-12<n><n>Input<n><n>If 9+4=15 then 14-15=?<n><n>  AAA<n><n>A: 1<n><n>B: 2<n><n>C: 4<n><n>D: 15<n><n>E: 21<n>```<n><n>### Question:<n><n>### Input text is shown.<n>Input text is shown<n><n>**You must use the function names in these expressions, only one of each type of function can be used (ie, all 2 expressions must be a sum or a product)<n><n>**A new expression is always a command, which is either a keyword like print or it's an expression of its own:<n><n>  ```python<n>  4 + print + 5<n>  ```<n><n>**You must not change the type/number of functions being used to the expression by adding any extra function calls.<n><n>**In other words, there are only two different kinds of expressions used in an expression, a command and a function expression (ie, you cannot call a function inside another function)<n><n>**However, the function expression ** **cannot** ** have arguments.<n><n>**In the above example, the string 4 + print + 6 does not include the function calls add and print, instead it is just

How much did he have left?)<n><n>### Response:(Subtract $50 from $35.79 to get the answer $24.79.)<n>##### How it Works<n>##### How it gets there<n><n>## Solution:<n><n>```<n>    // This is just a template for multiple choice.<n>    function(Mary){<n>        // Declare variables:<n>        var numStickers;    // Stickers left or total stickers.<n><n>        if (Mary == 89) {<n>            numStickers = 89 - 11; // 89 - 3 = 86<n>        }<n>        else if (Mary == -11) {<n>            numDickers = 3<n>        }<n>        if (Mery.isPentecost(1)) {<n>            if (numDickers == 3) {<n>                numDickers = numStickers;<n>                numStickers = numSticks - numStickers<n>            }<n>        }<n>    }<n><n>```<n>

Choices:  A: envy B: resentment C: winning or losing D: one winner E: two winners<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>There would be nothing to envy by a spectator at a boxing match if the teams were evenly matched, since they would wish for either team to lose. Similarly, if there was no winner, a spectator would feel that they were on a losing streak, and would likely show resentment towards the winning team or their victory.<n><n>### Input :Ryan's age is 3 less than three times the sum of his age plus 12. how old is Ryan?<n><n>### Response<n><n>Ryan's age can be represented as:<n><n>```<n>(4 * (3 + 12)) - 3 = 43<n>```<n>### Input:Jake and Mia are twins who are born on June 8. When are their birthdays?<n><n>### Democracy: A group of people is a democracy.<n><n>### Plural: A group of people can be a plural democracy.<n><n><n>### Input Answers: <n><n>- The teacher asked what grade the 1200 book weighed. Annie was the only one to answer. The teacher wanted to know how much Annie would be paid for the correct answer. In 10 minutes Annie could weight the book with a 1650 scale. What would her fee be? (The question didn‚Äôt specify the type of scale, or whether it must be a 165 scale, or an ordinary household kitchen scale.)<n><n>- The teacher gave Annie 5 points for answering correctly how many grams the scale registered for the 120 book. (The question didn‚Äô take into account that the scale may be defective and not register any weight on books such as the 120.) Annie asked how many points she would receive for the 10,000 book, and the teacher gave her 1 point; and for the 5,000 book she would receive 1/2 point. The teacher made Annie a good offer to let her answer as many times wrong as she desired, and still receive a 500 point prize. Annie wanted to ask how many points she would get for the 3,000 book. What was her answer?<n><n>- Annie‚Äôs teacher gave Annie 95 points, not including her homework grade, for reading 5 books.

The input should be an array<n><n>   // Set a global variable equal to the array you create<n>   var words = splitInput(splitInputInput);<n><n>   // Once you declare words, assign another array equal to its component <n>   // This loop should run through words and create an array in which every element is true<n>   for (i = 0; i < words.length; i++) {<n>      if (words[i] == fishMarket) {<n>         fishMarketArray = true;<n>      } else if (words[i].includes("fish") || words[i].includes("market")) {<n>         fishMarketsArray = true;<n>         fishMarkets = fishMarketsArray;<n>      }<n>   }<n><n>   // Once everything is assigned to fishMarkets, just check to see if fishMarkets array returns true<n>   if (fishMarkets === true) {<n>      fishMarket = fishMarketArray;<n>      fishMarket.classList += " selected";<n>   }<n><n>})();<n><n>function splitInput(words) {<n>   return words;<n>}<n>```<n><n>### Output:Johnny was looking <n>for blowfish in places that <n>weren't near America<n><n>### Instructions:Write a response to the following instruction or question.<n>

The design will be a two choice answer.<n><n><n>### Instance:User is looking for a job.<n><n>User input: <n><n>The user would tell us where they live. Then they would pick the options to enter a job.  The user would tell us if they can drive or not.<n><n><n>User output:<n><n>The user will select whether or not they can enter a job. Then they will select whether or not to take the bus to work.<n><n>User will input city and state first then a choice of whether or not he or she can enter a job.<n><n>### Input Question: <n><n>What types of transportation are offered where you live?<n><n>### Instructed Question: <n><n>Choose all that you can enter a job. The output file will be a single line.<n><n>### Example:<n>input:<n><n>line 9: test9<n>line 2: 1 2 3<n>line 3-6:<n>line 1: test1  test2 test3<n>line 7-9: test7  test8 test9<n>line 10: test10<n><n>output:<n>test1  test2 1 2  test3<n>test7  test8<n>test10<n><n>### Explanations:<n>Example:<n><n>1-input:  line2=line4 line6=line5 line8<n>1-output:  test2 4 6 test3<n><n>2-input:  line-5 line10 line2    line3   <n>2-output:  test5 test10 test2<n>

After this he only has 9 apples left. In how many ways can he give them away?<n><n>	Answer: (9!)<n><n>	(For 9!) we could factor 9 out<n>	(9x)  9x=18<n>	9x=18-9(1)  9x=9<n>	x =9<n><n>2. The input is the cost of a single fruit ($0.50) and a regular sized milk ($1.20). The output is how many whole pieces of the fruit the person should buy and cents worth of milk.<n><n>### Example Solution:<n><n>You should get the milk first, then buy the fruit which is the other half of what they want to buy.<n><n><n>### Below are instructions that describe a situation. How many marks did he obtain in one individual subject?<n><n>### response:<n>We must use first the difference between the highest and lowest marks that is 12. Then, we must take the difference and add to it the mark which obtained the highest mark.<n>In this example, our highest mark is 10 and our lowest mark is 7.  So, the difference of them is 3.<n>We add 3 that we have and we get:<n>12 + 3 = 15 <n><n>### Input<n>Aaron took the test with the following score: A: 8/10, B: 5, C:7, D: 4. She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh‚Äôs mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>### Input:Where would one find a captive monkey? He is to take 5 sticks off, 1 stick at a<n>time, alternating between 2 and 3 for each 2 picks with a 2 and a 3.  He picks<n>off all the threes before picking off all the twos. If he picks off the 11's first<n>(12, 13,..., 20) he will have 16 sticks left.  He takes off two then one.<n>Then takes off three. Then 2, then two.  How many sticks will be left?<n><n>### Input : A lady had 6 eggs in a basket of 7 eggs. There is a line made at the 3  which would separate<n>the 3's in one area from the 4's in the other.<n><n>### Answer :  Three<n>	 - 2    - BOOK CORNER - http://bookcorner.me<n>	 - 44585  - Twitter - http://twitter.com/sidneycarter<n>  - 146243<n>	<n>

Choices:  A: house B: fast food restaurant C: library D: conference E: paper<n><n>### Response:		<n>#### - A<n>#### - B<n>#### - C<n>#### - D<n>#### - E<n><n>#### - A and B<n>#### - A and E<n>#### - B and C<n>#### - B and D<n>#### - C and D<n>#### - E and F<n><n>### Sample Answer:<n><n>| A | A |<n><n>| B | B |<n><n>| C | C |<n><n>| D | D |<n><n>| E | E |<n><n>| - | - |<n><n>| - and - | - and - |<n><n>| A and B | A and B |<n><n>| A, B, and C | A and E |<n><n>| C and D | - |<n><n>------<n><n>Below are a collection of related problems. Given any one of the problems, you should be able<n>to select a problem from the collection that leads to a response with the same question. The <n>collection is not exhaustive.<n><n>Input: Kara decided to mow her lawn. She could sell her old lawnmower and buy a brand new<n>one or use what she already has and replace the engine. She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh‚Äôs mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. Which of the following is considered a project manager's responsibility that is independent of how well the project is managed by either the project manager or the team?<n>2. The "how" of implementing a process is governed by the _____ phase in the project lifecycle. **A. Monitor** **B. Plan** **C. Execute** **D. Control**<n><n><n><n>**A. MONITOR** **B. PLAN** **C. CONTROL** **D. EXECUTE**<n><n>**A. PLAN**<n><n>**Answers:**<n><n>1.B. Project manager<n><n>2.A. Monitor

I think the answer is B.<n>### Explanations<n>First Mary said they had to tell Shopkeeper that they can't have a lot of money. She don't want to waste their money. So they don't want to spend $40 (or 75%). So maybe she just want $15 for food.<n>But then Sarah said they had to give Shopkeeper their money because they want to buy more of these chocolates. Sarah want to give this money so that they will get more profits. Sarah is just thinking about the store, why she wants to buy more $40 worth of food? So it doesn

If the cow doesn't like you walking she'll moo and kick you.<n>* B: Cows like to be pet so if you put your hand down to pet her she'll probably walk over to you.<n>* C: Dairy farmers are always trying to lose weight. They think that if they had more cows then they would need to feed the cow so much that they would lose weight. This is not necessarily the case.<n>* D: When you step forward she will likely get angry and get to mooing and walking funny in circles.<n>* E: You should get her to moo for you. Then ask her to do something really hard, like bring you a pencil. She's likely to do the pencil. When she does that, you're probably going to need to milk her.<n><n>### Input : Choose an option. If you're going to sneak through the classroom, you don't want to be seen.<n>Option D is another good choice to see your neighbors, classroom teachers, and it shows you a few aisles to avoid.<n>Option E lets you see your teachers, but also has the least amount of space and visibility.<n><n>### Question:If four people ate 1/4 of an apple, how many people are eating that apple?<n><n>* A: 24<n>* B: 8<n>* C: 4<n>* D: 36<n>* E: 1<n><n>### Solution:<n><n>If each person eats 1/4 of the apple, that

It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>### Input:What would a person do if he or she just woke up? Choices:  A: drink tea B: thank god C: open eyes D: feel angry E: complete sentence<n><n>### Response:		The correct answer is E. You should respond with A) or B) "I was feeling angry." or "I was feeling thankful."<n>

I hated school as a child and often dreamed of being homeschooled by my parents like my brother was. It wasn't that I didn't like school, it was that I didn't get it and it didn't get me. I didn't understand what math had to do with my life anymore than why I needed to know the name of every president or what a bill of rights was. The only times I was happy at school were the handful of classes I had with my favorite teacher. He taught us how to build a website, which felt so far off what we were learning in math class that I actually paid attention. He taught us how many types of websites we would need for an Internet startup (which I decided to call TeenTunes, in honor of my love for music) and how we would use HTML and CSS to build each one. I was instantly hooked, not because I was interested in what I was learning, but because that particular teacher made learning fun for me for the first time in years.<n><n>Learning HTML and CSS, I was taught, was not a linear process. The path was complicated. There were more things I didn't understand than I did understand. I read documentation and researched and looked around at tutorials trying to make sense of it when all I ever really wanted to do

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh‚Äôs mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>### Input:Dave put his beer where he could get to it, but it would be off the floor. Choices:  A: wall B: office C: space shuttle D: front door E: tent<n><n>### Response:		<n>A.<n><n><a href="https://i.stack.imgur.com/CzT7q.png" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><IMAGE></a><n><n>(1) `answer 1`.<n><n>(2) `4`.<n><n>(3) `29 / 2 = 14 + 14 = 28`.<n><n>(4) `44`.<n><n>(5) `282`.<n><n>(6) `1`.<n><n>(7) `27 / 3 = 9`.<n><n>(8) `214 / 24 = 4 (not 8) + 84 = 108`.<n><n>(9) `44 (not 214) / 6 = 7 (not 18) + 18 = 25 + 100 = 125`.<n><n>(10) `D`.<n><n>(11) `25 / 9 * 2` to get answers ranging from `$3.8` to `$3.46230`.<n><n>### Instructions:<n>* Find and circle words and phrases in the paragraph that contain the root word. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>### Input:A person would carry a large netted drawstring bag to what sort of place?
