Choices:  A: celebrate B: have party C: hear crowd go mad D: create success E: reproduce<n><n>### Response:		Choose the answer A: celebrate<n><n>### Instructions<n><n>Input:<n>A person is trying to procreate<n><n>Choice:<n>How to try to procreate<n><n>Choices:  A: Celebrate<n><n>Output:<n>What would be considered a successful attempt at procreation.<n><n>### Input 2:<n>A:  celebrate<n><n>B:  party<n><n>C:  go mad<n><n>D:  create<n><n>E:  successful<n><n>### Input : What would be considered a success to when attempting procreation <n><n>### Choice   : D<n><n>### Output  : Create<n><n>### Comments:<n>```<n>I am not sure how the instruction is expecting me to answer this. The answer choice is D, and the input is A person is trying to procreation. I guess D means create if we are talking how successful is procreation attempt.<n><n>The choice A: celebrate made no sense. It just said to have a party or celebrate. There is no difference.<n><n>The Choice E: reproduce means to make children.<n><n>I am wondering if the input is a person talking, so you would ask them what is considered procreation, what they are doing to procreate, and what would the consider success.<n><n>I don't know.<n><n>```<n><n>### Output : Celebrate<n>What is considered procreation. The person try to procreate. They did not try to have a party or create. We would understand to ask them how successful they felt it was. They try to create a family, so they successful.<n><n>### Output C, what would be a consideration of procreation? To create a family. I thought that was weird, but that is what the instruction said. I chose celebration because that seemed the most common to me.<n><n>### Answer<n>The instruction was very specific. The instruction asked you to choose the word that made the most sense. It asked you to chose the word that was considered being successful. To me, D would include celebrate. D does not mean create. The output, I would say that was wrong. The instruction wanted the answer that was the most common.  Choosing celebrate was the most common.<n><n>### Explanation<n>The instruction gave me some context. I believe it did this due to the response

How long will it take?"<n><n>### Response:"The train will have to stop in Denver, where it will then travel at 45 m.p.h."<n><n>### Input:'The train's original velocity was 125 mph. So, the train will be travelling at 125 m.p.hr once it has passed Denver. When you are looking at the math, think about the fact that any additional time it will take on the road is not necessarily taken into consideration. We will consider the original 125 m, plus the time it took in Denver as it's new velocity, and hence the final velocity.'<n><n>### Input "Hamlet decides to kill his uncle Claudius, who he believes is responsible for the murder of his father. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>### Input:Where can you see a mammoth in NYC? If the mammoth is in the Natural History Museum then it had to exist in the prehistoric times<n>

Choices:  A: sail boats B: question authority C: high fives D: share things E: learn from each other<n><n>### Response:		Which of the four ways to engage in a pastime when traveling on liquid is most likely the correct answer?<n><n>### Explanation:<n><n>Explanation: When traveling along liquid, people are most likely to share things. People on a boat are together, and share food, which they may do with other boats in the vicinity. They share the water with other ships in the water, and would have to travel together in close range if they're racing. People on boats also share things from their boats to another boat. If they were having something, they would have at least one person hand their stuff to a person on the other boat. The only exception to this is fishing, which doesn't really count as a past time and people don't commonly learn from other boats about fishing.<n><n>### Inputs<n><n>### Mary had 89 stckers.  She used three lage stickers on the front of her journal and seven stickers each to six other pages of her journal then she used two small stickers to the 1/3 of her journal then she put the rest on her book shelf. How many stickers Mary have?<n><n>### 44<n><n>### 13<n><n>### The three boys, two bought a toy with the same price of $100.00. What is the difference in prices of the other two toys?<n><n>### $20<n><n>### The sum of the prices of the three toys is:<n><n>### $3000<n><n>### Write a program that counts the number of 8s in a string of numbers.<n><n>### ## code 8<n><n>### In the example: 68816224264955158, there is 3.65786291970000<n>### of 8 as the string.<n>###<n>### Sample Input: 6882971239836444<n>### Sample Output: 3.6588076587000000<n><n><n>```python<n>    n = 0 # initialize the counter<n>    for i in range(0, len(t)): # loop through each char<n>    if (t[i
